conference.title: FOSDEM 2008
conference.subtitle: Free and Open source Software Developers' European Meeting

event.title: Unicoding With PHP 6
event.abstract: The Unicode support is the #1 feature in PHP 6. Come to this session and find out what this means for you and how you can take advantage of it.
event.description:
Don't be left behind as the software world moves towards language and cultural sensitivity. Speaking Unicode is all the rage these days and this session will show what PHP has learned and how easy it will be to work with multilingual text.

This talk will provide an overview of the most salient features of the Unicode support and illustrate the new internationalization features with a variety of demos on topics such as: * Character set conversion * Text boundary analysis * Working with international dates and calendars * Transliteration and text normalization * Working with character sets and properties

event.title: Perl 6
event.abstract: Patrick Michaud will talk about the Perl 6 programming language from a variety of perspectives, and targeting a number of different audiences.
event.description:
Patrick will look at some of the changes and improvements that Perl 6 has made as a language over previous versions of Perl, as well as many of the technical details of its implementation.

Along the way he'll also take a look at Parrot, and see how it is progressing to become a common runtime platform for Perl, Python, PHP, Ruby, Javascript, and many other dynamic languages.

event.title: Battle for Wesnoth
event.abstract:
David White will talk about the Battle for Wesnoth's development from a technical point of view. He'll discuss what has been successful during the project's development, and what lessons have been learned.

White will present details of the design and implementation of the game as a case study in building a Free game.

Attention will also go to the currently low number of quality Free games, and what can be done about it.

event.title: Globulation 2
event.abstract: Stéphane will give a technical presentation of Globulation 2, an open source strategy game.
event.description:
Stéphane will first present the overall software architecture, the design choices and some philosophical considerations about strategic games and the rationale behind Globulation 2.

Then he will detail some subsystems of particular interest for the community, such as the GUI, the path-finder, the scripting language and the network. He will conclude by a critical analysis of the development process. The presentation will save time for questions.

event.title: How a large scale opensource project works
event.abstract: How the FreeBSD Project Works
event.description:
The FreeBSD Project is one of the oldest and most successful open source operating system projects, seeing wide deployment across the IT industry. From the root name servers, to top tier ISPs, to core router operating systems, to firewalls, to embedded appliances, you can't use a networked computer for ten minutes without using FreeBSD dozens of times.

Part of FreeBSD's reputation for quality and reliability comes from the nature of its development organization -- driven by a hundreds of highly skilled volunteers, from high school students to university professors. And unlike most open source projects, the FreeBSD Project has developers who have been working on the same source base for over twenty years.

But how does this organization work? Who pays the bandwidth bills, runs the web servers, writes the documentation, writes the code, and calls the shots? And how can developers in a dozen time zones reach agreement on the time of day, let alone a kernel architecture?

This presentation will attempt to provide, in 45 minutes, a brief if entertaining snapshot into what makes FreeBSD run.

event.title: Tux with Shades, Linux in Hollywood
event.abstract:
Gabrielle Pantera and Robin Rowe will talk about Linux in the motion picture industry, especially its use at the major studios. This community is an upside-down parallel universe where Linux is everywhere, and Windows and Mac are niche operating systems. They'll talk about how the movie Titanic touched off a mass migration to Linux, what Linux tools are used and how. The result is virtually every blockbuster or animated feature in theaters today is made using Linux tools.

Some movie clips will be screened to show technically and visually how Linux has become the #1 operating system for making blockbuster films, and implications for the future will be discussed.
event.description:
At first, studios had no choice but to develop Linux applications in-house. The film industry has millions of lines of Linux code, both desktop applications and server pipelines. Studio Linux programmers write code in C++, Python, Perl, and Java. What does all this secret proprietary Linux code do? And, why do they do parallel programming with grid computing? How does the film industry use renderfarms with thousands of CPUs?

Studios no longer have to develop their own tools. They can buy the Linux tools they need off the shelf. Commercial Linux motion picture tools available today include Combustion, FrameCycler, Houdini, Maya, Mental Ray, Nuke, Piranha, Platform LXF, RaveHD, RenderMan, SoftImage|XSI and more. What are all these tools for and where did they come from? What do they cost? How did a vibrant commercial Linux applications market emerge in this industry, and why nowhere else?

The film industry has funded open source development. CinePaint, Wine, and FLTK are open source projects that have received financial support from the film industry in the past. FLTK was developed at Digital Domain to support their proprietary application development and then released as LGPL. What kind of crazy open source world is this where copyright zealot Disney funds development of LGPL code in Wine to replace Windows? Why isn't the film industry doing more to support open source development?

event.title: JRuby
event.abstract: This session will talk about the challenges during the JRuby development process, including the lack of a Ruby language spec, the numerous C-based extensions to the Ruby interpreter, and the difficulty of refactoring and evolving a working language implementation in-place.
event.description:
In two years, the JRuby community has brought JRuby from a slow, broken state to being the fastest complete Ruby 1.8 implementation in the world. Improvements to the runtime and interpreter combined with a JVM bytecode compiler have shown that even heavily dynamic languages can be made fast on the JVM. And the JRuby community has gone the extra mile to port native libraries necessary to run real-world Ruby apps like Rails.

JRuby is an OSS success story.

This session will talk about the challenges during the JRuby development process, including the lack of a Ruby language spec, the numerous C-based extensions to the Ruby interpreter, and the difficulty of refactoring and evolving a working language implementation in-place.

We'll enumerate the many ways community contributions have made JRuby a success, and talk about how the JRuby story could apply to OSS projects in general. And we'll walk through a timeline of the past two years, showing JRuby's open-source evolution step by step.

event.title: Status update of Software Patents
event.abstract: Status update on software patents in Europe.
event.description:
Pieter Hintjens, past president of the FFII will give us an update on the current state of things regarding software patents in Europe.

He'll speak about the politicization of open standards and software patents, and where we stand in the two wars we're fighting, one at the international level (OOXML hits ISO) and one in Europe (software patents).

event.title: Lightning Opening Talk
event.abstract: The main goal is to buffer the time between the opening of the room, and the first real lightning talk. If time permits, there will be a lightning talk about the lightning talks: with statistics about the proposals and acceptances, and the story of how these lightning talks are organized.
event.description:
The FOSDEM Lightning Talks are organized by Mattias 'Tias' Guns since 2007, to allow smaller projects to expose themselves to the large developer audience of FOSDEM.

The Lightning Talks can be described as the 15 minutes of frame for all small to medium sized open source projects. During exactly 15 minutes, one person gets to present his project or an aspect of it. All Lightning Talks happen in a large room that can host up to 300 people.

event.title: Electronic Frontier Foundation
event.abstract: EFF monitors and intervenes when your digital freedoms are threatened -- whether its free speech online, intellectual property balance, or preserving open innovation. Eddan and Erik will talk about EFF's active campaigns in Europe, discuss upcoming policy issues for free and open source globally, and share what EFF and you can do about it.
event.description: EFF is a member-supported civil liberties organization that has been fighting for digital rights across the world for over 15 years.

event.title: Open Trusted Computing: towards trusted and secure computing
event.abstract:
Trusted computing in open source world

  • Key concepts and definitions
  • Trusted platform module
  • Open source applications and libraries of trusted computing
  • Status of TC components in Linux: Hardware and software support
  • DRM and Trusted Computing
  • Future of Trusted Computing
event.description: The Open Trusted Computing (OpenTC) consortium is an Research & Development project focusing on the development of trusted and secure computing systems based on open source software. The project targets traditional computer platforms as well as embedded systems such as mobile phones. The suggested architecture is applicable to a wide range of platform types, e.g. servers, GRID technology, mobile phones and industrial automation. It provides basic building blocks for complex, distributed scenarios with inherent, multilateral trust and security capabilities. The framework will be built around the "Trusted Platform Module" (TPM) specified by the Trusted Computing Group (TCG) and the new generation of x86 CPUs from Intel and AMD. To enable maximum community benefit, project results will be integrated in and distributed as Open Source software, supporting Linux in particular.

event.title: Zapcat: monitoring Java applications
event.abstract: This lightning talk gives a tour of Zapcat. It shows how to explore memory use of a Tomcat application server, find garbage collector issues, thread use and thread deadlock. The talk closes with a practical guide how to start monitoring your own Java applications.
event.description: Zapcat is a bridge between Java JMX and the Zabbix monitoring tool. It allows system administrators to monitor Java applications without having to learn Java. Zapcat provides templates and plugins for the JVM, Hibernate, Tomcat and the Openfire XMPP server. The documentation gives step-by-step howto's for all of these components, plus Jetty and Oracle's IAS/OC4J server.

event.title: Terracotta: network attached memory for the JVM
event.abstract: This talk will highlight the fundamentals and principles behind JVM-level clustering with Terracotta. A short code example will be evolved over several steps to provide a feel of Terracotta is used in practice.
event.description: Terracotta works like network attached memory and plugs into the Java Virtual Machine to transparently bring clustering, scalability and high availability to existing and new software.

event.title: Dacco: open source dictionaries
event.abstract:
This lightning talk will provide a quick overview of a different type of open source project: an English-Catalan Dictionary. We will give a short explanation about how it is being implemented, which methods and tools are used, its history and future direction.

We will also explain what Catalan is, why an open source approach is important and how people can contribute.

We will introduce Dacco's tools and features including qdacco (a GPLv3 desktop application which allows users to query the dictionary and, through integration with Festival, hear how words are pronounced), an HTML search engine, PDF files and an iGoogle gadget.

The main goal of this talk is to introduce people to the concept of Open Source Dictionaries and encourage them to develop their own.
event.description:
Dacco (Diccionari Anglès-Català de Codi Obert - Open Source English-Catalan Dictionary). The project hosts two dictionaries: an English-Catalan dictionary and a Catalan-English dictionary. The project is trying to fill the gap in the world of dictionaries: there aren't any free (as freedom) Catalan-English dictionaries and there isn't any good Catalan dictionary for English speaking people because of the lack of potential buyers.

The Dacco project is developing a dictionary through regular international contributors who add, change and improve the word descriptions constantly. Nowadays Dacco has aproximately 15000 entries. We also use internet resources like photo links when a description isn't just enough, dictionary is oftenly updated, etc. There are versions for Catalan speakers and for English speakers with different notes and examples.

Dacco base files (XML) have GPL license and we also provide PDF files (under Creative Commons license), Firefox search plugins, qdacco software, HTML standard form search tool, etc.

The Dacco project was formally started on May 2003, though Linda Oxnard (the founder) started working on it on 2001.

event.title: Indywiki: visually browsing wikipedia pages
event.abstract: In this short talk I am willing to present indywiki, how one can use it to browse Wikipedia and what advantages this might offer over a web browser, plus a few thing about indywiki architecture and current work/research .
event.description: Indywiki is an open source project that aims to explore different ways of visually browsing wikipedia pages.

event.title: Kettle: extracting, transforming and loading data
event.abstract: With the lightning talk, Matt wants to take a first stab at bridging the gap between two worlds: the general open source world, and the Open Source Business Intelligence world. Unfortunately it will not be possible to explain the whole field of BI in 15 minutes, so the focus will be on Matt's line of expertise, ETL and the Kettle project more specific.
event.description:
Kettle basically is an extremely fast tool to extract data from many different sources, such as web pages, excel documents, databases, you name it. (E = Extraction in ETL)

We can transparently grab that data and then manipulate, transform or process that data in just about any possible way you can imagine. (T = Transformation in ETL)

Then, after combining data, changing it, mapping values and whatnot, you can store or load the result in whatever format or medium you like, including text files and all possible databases. (L = Loading in ETL)

Some examples:

  • Load data from text files, XML files to store it into a database
  • Export of database(s) to text-file(s) or other databases
  • Import of data into databases, ranging from text-files to excel sheets
  • Data migration between database applications
  • Exploration of data in existing databases (tables, views, etc.)
  • Information enrichment by looking up data in various information stores
(databases, text-files, excel sheets and more )
  • Data cleaning by applying complex conditions in data transformations
  • Application integration
  • Data warehouse population with built-in support for slowly changing
dimensions, junk dimensions and much, much more. To do all these things we provide an easy to use graphical user interface. For a screen shot, see here: http://www.pentaho.com/images/transformation_screenshot.png One of the first things that was done by Kettle (and myself 4-5 years ago) was the capturing of the traffic data for the Flanders Traffic Centre (Vlaams Verkeerscentrum) in Wilrijk: http://www.verkeerscentrum.be/verkeersinfo/default This source data is updated every minute and loaded from thousands of sources accross the state, referenced, cleaned and loaded in a single Terabyte database containing years of history and billions of rows of data. That database is then used to do traffic pattern analyses, traffic density reports, planning of road works, etc.

event.title: Alfresco: fresh document management approach
event.abstract:
The talk will be about:

  • Alfresco functionalities.(5min)
  • Alfresco software architecture.(5 min)
  • Alfresco business model.(5 min)
event.description: Alfresco is an DM/WCM fresh approach project. The entire source code is published under the GPL license and is based on the JAVA stack.

event.title: Stylebase for Eclipse: sharing software architectural models
event.abstract: First, a very quick look at background information (software architecture design, modeling and patterns) would be taken, explaining the benefits of maintaining an architectural knowledge base. Then the vision and current status of our project will be described. We would tell about what the software can do at the moment and how we plan to improve it in the future. If desired, a nice looking recorded demo can be shown.
event.description: Stylebase for Eclipse is tool for sharing and reusing software architectural knowledge. Stylebase for Eclipse helps to maintain a knowledge base of software architectural models. The knowledge base can store architectural patterns, design patterns, reference architectures, macro and micro architectures et cetera. Each model is associated with HTML-formatted textual documentation and a number of searchable properties. Users can maintain both local and shared repository and download/upload models between the two. Please visit http:stylebase.tigris.org <http:stylebase.tigris.org/> for source code and more information.

event.title: Bongo Project: simple e-mail and calendar server
event.abstract: I would like to present a talk to highlight the project as we have not had much exposure to the great outdoors. I would like to show Bongo's feature set and also try and grow the community around the project.
event.description: Simple e-mail and calenda server. Bongo emerged from the Hula Project just as Novell sold the Hula business to Messaging Architects. The majority of the code has been re-written since then and we aim to grow stronger.

event.title: XMMS2: redesign of the XMMS music player
event.abstract: A description of XMMS2, its new architecture and the challenges that remain.
event.description: XMMS2 is a redesign of the XMMS music player. It features a client-server model, allowing multiple (even simultaneous!) user interfaces, both textual and graphical. All common audio formats are supported using plugins. On top of this, there is a flexible media library to organize your music.

event.title: OpenAFS: cross-platform enterprise class distributed filesystem
event.abstract: This talk will present a developers view of OpenAFS. It will briefly detail why OpenAFS is still a compelling filesystem for today's enterprise users, examine the challenges of maintaining an old code base across a wide range of operating systems, and discuss the opportunities that this stable base presents for future development work. In particular we'll look at my ongoing work to reintroduce disconnected operation.
event.description: OpenAFS is a cross-platform enterprise class distributed filesystem. AFS started life at Carnegie Mellon University and was then marketed as a commercial product by Transarc, and later by IBM. In 2000 IBM open-sourced the codebase, creating the OpenAFS project. OpenAFS continues to maintain and enhance this code, producing file system modules for Linux, AIX, HPUX, Irix, Solaris and Mac OS X from a common source tree. Microsoft Windows support is also provided.

event.title: Squeak: modern development environment for Smalltalk.
event.abstract: The talk will give an overview of Squeak the language, the platform, and of the recent advances in the larger Smalltalk community: the Seaside web framework, the release of GNU Smalltalk 3.0.
event.description: Squeak is a modern open-source development environment for the classic Smalltalk-80 programming language. Despite being the first purely object-oriented language and environment, Smalltalk is in many ways still far ahead of its successors in promoting a vision of an environment where everything is an object, and anything can change at run-time.

event.title: IOGrind: locating I/O performance problems
event.abstract:
I/O latency is the dominating factor in desktop application startup performance. It is also one of the hardest things to measure in a reliable and deterministic fashion. Wall-clock timings on just-booted, quiescent systems give unfeasibly large jitter making optimising cold-start times extremely difficult.

Measures of warm vs. cold start show eg. 80% of an OO.o cold start is pure I/O time. I/O grind is a new valgrind based tool that can record & simulate I/O patterns, allowing not only targeted optimisation of applications, but deterministic comparisons of kernel I/O algorithms. Kernel optimisation is often focused on more tractable CPU cycles, however the big wins are in I/O behavior - saving only one seek on cold OO.o startup, is the equivalent of a 500 cycle win on every system call emitted.
event.description: IOGrind is a tool for locating I/O related performance problems, that hurt application cold-start times.

event.title: Amarok 2
event.abstract: Amarok 2 – in the intersection of Free Software and Free Culture. The Free Software and Free Culture movements have much in common, but used to scarcely interact. Amarok2 is bringing Creative Commons licensed content to more users by making it easy to discover new music, benefiting users and artists alike.
event.description:
Expanding on the work started in Amarok 1.4.4 with the integration of the Magnatune.com music store, Amarok 2 explores the possibilities for integrating and collaborating with online music services, in particular the ones who license their content under a Creative Commons license. This integration makes a lot of sense as it directly benefits both the users of Amarok as well as the online services, and hence their artists.

This talk will cover some of the general ideas behind the integration, how it is being accomplished at a technical level, and what the future plans and possibilities are. Of course the talk will also include a live demo of the current state of Amarok 2.

event.title: Battle for Wesnoth
event.abstract:
David White will talk about the Battle for Wesnoth's development from a technical point of view. He'll discuss what has been successful during the project's development, and what lessons have been learned.

White will present details of the design and implementation of the game as a case study in building a Free game.

Attention will also go to the currently low number of quality Free games, and what can be done about it.

event.title: BSDA exam session 1
event.abstract: BSDA exam session #1

event.title: BSDA exam session 2
event.abstract: BSDA exam session #2

event.title: About the BSDA certification
event.abstract: After the hype of the nineties, IT and IT knowledge became "common": everybody could configure a web server, any home user can set up a firewall, and we got the impression that there was nothing difficult about the net and its applications. Yet there is much more to it, and thus the BSD certification was created in order to separate the good from the bad, the people with the real knowledge from the masses who make the net an unsafe and badly maintained.
event.description:
• Why do we need yac (yet another certification)?
  • What are the different types of certification?
  • Certifications from the point of view of employees and employers.
  • Comparison between certifications.
  • Progress report: where do we stand, available languages, can I do the exam in my country,
  • sponsors and the cost of developing exams, what certifications are available and which are planned?
  • What do you need to know? Who is the intended audience? An overview of the exam objectives in the categories of system administration, installing and upgrading, security, files and file systems, user account management, network administration and UNIX skills.
  • Commitment to testing real-world skills, not just a paper exam. Who defined these objectives? An overview of the Task Survey Analysis.
  • Study resources: where can you find training materials, how to prepare for the exam.
  • How will we test your knowledge: Testing methodology, the importance of using psychometrics.

event.title: Pluggable real-time monitoring with dstat
event.abstract: Dstat is a versatile replacement for vmstat, iostat, netstat, nfsstat and ifstat. Dstat overcomes some of their limitations and adds some extra features, more counters and flexibility. Dstat is handy for monitoring systems during performance tuning tests, benchmarks or troubleshooting.
event.description:
Dstat allows you to view all of your system resources instantly, you can eg. compare disk usage in combination with interrupts from your IDE controller, or compare the network bandwidth numbers directly with the disk throughput (in the same interval).

The aim of this talk is to present dstat to the FOSDEM audience. At first explain what it was designed for and why it displays information in this way. The usefulness to correlate counters by selecting only those values on a case-by-case basis. I'd like to highlight the different use cases and show the potential of dstat as it is today in comparison with vmstat, top and other tools. How one can create raw data and graphs and what kind of plugins currently exist. Before diving into the internals, I'd like to pinpoint some of the known limitations and performance aspects of using a scripting language.

event.title: Introduction to CentOS
event.abstract: The reasons why you need an enterprise Linux distro.

event.title: Crystalspace3D
event.abstract: Crystalspace3D is a free cross-platform software development kit for realtime 3D graphics, in particular games.
event.description: This talk is about Crystal Space and Crystal Entity Layer. Crystal Space is an Open Source platform for developing 3D programs. It is not specific to games but that's the most important usage. Crystal Entity Layer is a game layer sitting on top of Crystal Space making it easier to create games. In this talk Jorrit will discuss the modular structure of the engine and how this structure enables the project to be very flexible and extendable. He will go over various plugins in Crystal Space and discuss how they interact with each other. Also he will explain the Crystal Entity Layer plugins and what they add on top of Crystal Space. Other topics that will also be touched in this presentation are Blender, blender2crystal, and the Apricot project.

event.title: Apt Xapian Index
event.abstract: Apt Xapian Index, or, Everything You Always Wanted to Index About Debian Packages, But were Afraid to Ask.
event.description:
Enrico has recently put together a new, extensible way of indexing information about Debian packages that complements the Apt index.

This provides a base to build more advanced package managers, with features like fast searches, stemmed searches, search as you type, debtags filters, and leveraging data not found in the Packages file, like popcon ratings and ratings provided by 3rd parties.

During the talk he'll present the index, showing both ways to query it and ways to add indexing plugins to index extra packaging data of your choice.

event.title: netconf - design and overview
event.abstract: netconf is a novel network configuration management system, designed with modern network infrastructures and the needs of roaming users in mind. In this talk, I present the design of netconf, as well as a brief run-through of its code base. I want to make it easier for others to contribute and join the development team.
event.description:
netconf is a daemon designed from the bottom up with only minimal functionality. It uses an event-driven model and well-defined, bidirectional interfaces, which make it possible to integrate advanced functionality:

  • link and location autodetection;
  • configuration of printers, smarthosts, proxies, etc. from DHCP data;
  • LinkLocal addressing;
  • wireless LAN;
  • VPN;
  • firewalling;
  • advanced routing and traffic control, including bridging, various user interfaces (including the NetworkManager GUI), and so on.
All of these are implemented as scripts for maximum configurability and flexibility.

event.title: Packaging with git (or $DSCM)
event.abstract: Pierre will talk about many new tools that happened in the last 2 years, around the debian packaging, applied to git because it's what I use, but probably many of the ideas can be used for any distributed SCM out there.
event.description: One part of the talk should be about how this techniques make the contribution back to upstream easier. Some of the bits will probably be quite git specifics though. Though the whole thing may move a bit when I've prepared some material for the talk.

event.title: Cross-building Debian and Tdebs
event.abstract: A lot of progress has been made in preparing Debian for embedded devices in the last year. This talk describes the common problems arising from cross building, improvements being made to existing Debian infrastructure to ease cross compiling and the problems that remain.
event.description: Also included is a description of the Emdebian implementation of Tdebs - translation packages with secondary repository and cache support and how this support can be implemented in Debian.

event.title: Linux on the PS3
event.abstract: Sony's Playstation 3 is an interesting platform to run Linux on and start hacking: first it comes with a pre-installed Xen hypervisor to easily install any OS without erasing the original gaming OS. Furthermore IBM provides a complete C/C++ SDK based on gcc to leverage the amazing Cell BE CPU.
event.description:
The Cell BE is an 8 cores chip of which 7 SPEs are optimised to perform Single Instruction Multiple Data processing and the remaining hyperthreaded PowerPC core (aka the PPE) plays the role of a conductor. For numerical applications a single Cell BE can run up to 200 GFLOPS where a typical Intel Core2Duo theoretically gives 30.

The talk will be organised as follows: we first introduce the general architecture of the PS3 system, then we focus on SIMD programming with sample program written for both the PPE's Altivec instruction set and the SPEs. Then we will finally show how to use Direct Memory Access to feed the cores with data without stall by implementing double-buffering with the DMA API of libspe2.

event.title: Modest, email client for embedded systems
event.abstract:
"Modest" is a project to build a fully open-source email program, designed specifically for embedded devices like the Nokia N800 and N810.

Starting December 2007, installable packages are available, with frequent updates. Modest uses the Tinymail e-mail framework.
event.description: Dirk-Jan Binnema has been part of the project since its inception, and in this talk, he'll go through some of the challenges of building a user-friendly e-mail client, taking into account the strengths and limitations of an embedded platform. Both technical and non-technical issues will be discussed, and the way they were handled.

event.title: Building blocks for Embedded Power Management
event.abstract: The range of embedded devices, and the variety of their uses makes the design of embedded power management a complicated problem. This talk will cover the basic building blocks of embedded power management which are common across a range of devices, and how they can be combined to construct a full power-management solution tailored to a specific platform.
event.description:
The talk will focus on the linux kernel and cover the steps required to implement/port the power management features to a new platform.

Topics covered:

  • clock framework
  • suspend and resume
  • Managing idle time
* dynamic tick * deferrable timers * CPUidle * PowerTOP
  • Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS)
* CPUfreq

event.title: Xen for Secure Isolation on ARM11
event.abstract: Using Xen for Secure Isolation on ARM11 Based Mobile Devices or Yet Another Xen ARM Port. MontaVista is implementing a port of Xen to the ARM architecture tailored for use on mobile devices. Although there are reports of existing Xen ARM ports, those ports are either [[http://www.cs.ubc.ca/grads/resources/thesis/May06/Ferstay_Daniel.pdf incomplete], abandoned and/or have not been publicly released. MontaVista is therefore implementing yet another Xen ARM port which will indeed be publicly released.
event.description:
1. Our primary goal for porting Xen to the ARM architecture is to provide secure isolation between two or more Xen guest domains on mobile devices utilizing ARM11 based processors. To achieve this primary goal, we intend to leverage the ongoing Xen Security Modules (XSM) FLux Advanced Security Kernel (FLASK) work as part of our Xen based ARM Secure Isolation strategy.
  2. As a secondary goal, we intend to implement our Xen ARM port in a manner which will facilitate rapid porting to new ARM processors and/or machines. This secondary goal will be achieved via inclusion of the excellent ARM multi-processor/multi-machine support implementation present in the current Linux-2.6 kernel into our Xen ARM port.
  3. Our tertiary goal is to incorporate ARM Linux kernel initialisation parameter support into Xen to set up the initial Xen ARM machine environment thus facilitating use of Xen on existing ARM targets without requiring target bootloader customisations. As of this writing, we have completed the initial bring up of the Xen ARM idle domain on a QEMU Versatile/PB ARM926EJ-S based target but have not yet completed bring up of the Xen mini-OS and/or Linux guest domains. It is anticipated that we will have substantially completed our Xen ARM porting efforts in time to present a fully functional Xen ARM port at the LCA Virtualisation Miniconf.
This presentation will provide:
  1. An architectural overview of the MontaVista Xen ARM port
  2. Background details of the MontaVista Xen ARM porting efforts to date
  3. Current status of the MontaVista Xen ARM port
  4. Live demonstration of Xen on an ARM11 based target
  5. Next steps for the Xen ARM port

event.title: Getting one million to know Linux
event.abstract: The "GNU/Linux Matters" community wants an extra million people to know Linux in 2008. Where are these people to be found, and how do we communicate with them?
event.description: The conference will show the relevance of down-to-earth communication and basic market-thinking for free software and Linux. Olivier will relate experience gained from the trenches of the Linux internet advocacy, developing the GNU/Linux Matters non-profit organization.

event.title: SELinux don't just switch it off
event.abstract: Security-Enhanced Linux (SELinux) is a Linux feature that provides a variety of security policies, including U.S. Department of Defense style mandatory access controls, through the use of Linux Security Modules (LSM) in the Linux kernel. It is not a Linux distribution, but rather a set of modifications that can be applied to Unix-like operating systems, such as Linux and BSD.
event.description: Its architecture strives to streamline the volume of software charged with security policy enforcement, which is closely aligned with the TCSEC (Orange Book) requirement for TCB minimization (applicable to evaluation classes B3 and A1) but is quite unrelated to the least privilege requirement (B2, B3, A1) as is often claimed. The germinal concepts underlying SELinux can be traced to several earlier projects by the U.S. National Security Agency.

event.title: Transifex: A new perspective in translation management
event.abstract: During the past months, Fedora is investing heavily in re-engineering its translation workflow. By supporting more than 5 different version control systems for source development and having more than 2000 translators, challenges surface all the time. A coherent plan is needed to allow translators to conveniently contribute to many upstream projects by hiding the technical details of low-level tools, to give to newly created projects the ability to easily locate prospective translators, and to remove the necessity for maintainers to continually keep their translations in sync with upstream
event.description:
To ease the process of translation contributions, a novel tool called "Transifex" was developed, promising to solve the above problems. It provides translators with a generic interface to remote version control systems, blending nicely with their existing workflow. With Transifex, a translation community is able to contribute directly to many upstream projects, without the need to create new accounts or learn the tricks of new versioning systems. At the same time, project maintainers can easily reach out and receive contributions from thousands of translators spanning many established communities, without being required to relocate their code, or manage accounts and bug reports for translations.

This talk will present this new vision in translation workflows, and explain how it fundamentally changes the way translations are contributed to open source projects. It will base its examples on the challenging landscape of the Fedora Translation Project, feature a live demo of the system, and lay down a long list of exciting future plans.

event.title: FreeBSD 7.0 and beyond
event.abstract: n/a

event.title: SNMP monitoring
event.abstract: n/a

event.title: Hacking OpenJDK & Friends
event.abstract: Hear about directions in hacking Free Java from the front lines

event.title: Mobile Java
event.abstract: Take your freedom to the max! Make your Free Java mobile.
event.description: What if you want to scale up or down your VM or class library. Is it easy to switch between completely different "full" and "small" versions of the core class libraries? How do you make a VM as flexible as possible to adopt to the available resources and core classes? What has the Mobile and Embedded community been up to this last year?

event.title: VM Rumble, Porting and Architectures
event.abstract: There are lots of runtimes able to execute your java byte code. But which one is the best, coolest, smartest, easiest portable or just simply the most fun?
event.description:
Various virtual machine hackers will each give a short presentation on what makes their runtime special and fun to work with. What cool things they have been doing this last year. What are their plans for next year.

What can other runtimes learn from their experiences.

And how can YOU help! The session will end with a general VM discussion.

  • Kaffe (Dalibor Topic)
  • JamVM (Robert Lougher)
  • HotSpot (Peter Kessler)
  • JikesRVM (Ian Rogers)
  • CACAO (Christian Thalinger)
  • ikvm (Jeroen Frijters)
  • Zero-assembler Port (Gary Benson)

event.title: Welcome to the Free Java Meeting - Introductions
event.abstract: Welcome and introduction to the projects, people and themes that make up the Free Java Meeting at Fosdem.
event.description: After welcoming and introducing the people and projects in the room various people from GNU Classpath, OpenJDK and Sun will look back on the past year and try to look into the future. There will also be a short presentation on the OpenJDK Community Innovator's Challenge.

event.title: Women in Java Technology
event.abstract: Female programmers are rare. Female Java programmers are even more rare. As female Java programmers ourselves, our interest in this issue led us to start Duchess, an organization to support and promote women in the Java industry and hopefully to encourage more to join.

event.title: Globulation 2
event.abstract: Stéphane will give a technical presentation of Globulation 2, an open source strategy game.
event.description:
Stéphane will first present the overall software architecture, the design choices and some philosophical considerations about strategic games and the rationale behind Globulation 2.

Then he will detail some subsystems of particular interest for the community, such as the GUI, the path-finder, the scripting language and the network. He will conclude by a critical analysis of the development process. The presentation will save time for questions.

event.title: More Clutter: Animating the Platform
event.abstract: This talk is about the Clutter project, its current state, the impending release of the new stable version, and its possibilities as a default animations library for the GNOME platform.
event.description: In this talk Emmanuele will expose what Clutter is (in case people haven't been following Planet GNOME or haven't been able to attend the Clutter talk at GUADEC'07), its usage and the suitability for having applications include more organic and useful animations for their user interface, similarly to what Apple provides with its Core Animations API.

event.title: GNOME Developer Kit
event.abstract: We will discuss motivation behind creating the GNOME Developer Kit, possible uses, and perhaps discuss what else we can do with it.
event.description: We will also discuss current GNOME Love initiatives, and how we use the developer kit to lower the barrier of entry and make the GNOME community a better place to work, play, and hang out. Information on the GNOME Developer Kit can be found at http://live.gnome.org/GnomeDeveloperKit

event.title: Elisa - Enjoy your multimedia world
event.abstract: The talk is about Elisa, the open source media center developed by Fluendo.
event.description: In this talk Alessandro will highlight some of the new features that make Elisa one of the most appealing and easy to use media centers. I will focus particularly on the shiny new user interface and on online media browsing capabilities.

event.title: GUPnP: UPnP made easy
event.abstract: Zeeshan will briefly explain what UPnP is all about, followed by an introduction to GUPnP API with special emphasis on the server-side API.
event.description: He will also explain how it is so easy to implement your own UPnP devices using GUPnP with the help of an example Light Bulb device that implements two simple services. I will also explain why GUPnP deserves to be the default UPnP stack on maemo and GNOME platforms.

event.title: Mobile Manager
event.abstract: Mobile Manager stems from a previous commercial project called Escritorio movistar, which is an end-user 3G connectivity app distributed by Telefónica España (commercial name movistar) in order to ease the usage of its mobile data networks. We've opened the source of this app and our next step is to promote the most valuable core component, the Mobile Manager, within the community.
event.description:
Mobile Manager is a D-Bus service and a UI core with some useful widgets for handling of several aspects of 3G connection devices (PIN/PUK dialogs, signal strength polling, roaming...) as well as connection initiation. Mobile Manager is developed in Python/GTK and D-Bus and is fully compatible with GNOME and FreeDesktop.

As part of our plan to promote Mobile Manager, we're studying the possibility of having it integrated with GNOME System Tools and other network applications; we would also like to discuss about this dissemination plans at the dev talk.

Although the project has been originated inside an operator (Telefónica España), our commitement is one of total operator- and network- agnosticism, so that the component can be used in whatever 3G scnearios.

event.title: Pigment: Towards a desktop scene graph
event.abstract: This talk is about the Pigment library. The project has been initiated by Fluendo at the same time as the Elisa media center, from the observation that the GNOME desktop lacks a library for easily creating rich application user interfaces.
event.description: Pigment used to be linked to Elisa, but it is now evolving on its own trying to attract more developers. This talk will expose the current Pigment API, how it integrates in the desktop, and the plans for the upcoming/next versions.

event.title: Welcome to the GNOME devroom
event.abstract: Welcome to the GNOME developer room at FOSDEM 2008; opening talk.

event.title: JRuby
event.abstract: This session will talk about the challenges during the JRuby development process, including the lack of a Ruby language spec, the numerous C-based extensions to the Ruby interpreter, and the difficulty of refactoring and evolving a working language implementation in-place.
event.description:
In two years, the JRuby community has brought JRuby from a slow, broken state to being the fastest complete Ruby 1.8 implementation in the world. Improvements to the runtime and interpreter combined with a JVM bytecode compiler have shown that even heavily dynamic languages can be made fast on the JVM. And the JRuby community has gone the extra mile to port native libraries necessary to run real-world Ruby apps like Rails.

JRuby is an OSS success story.

This session will talk about the challenges during the JRuby development process, including the lack of a Ruby language spec, the numerous C-based extensions to the Ruby interpreter, and the difficulty of refactoring and evolving a working language implementation in-place.

We'll enumerate the many ways community contributions have made JRuby a success, and talk about how the JRuby story could apply to OSS projects in general. And we'll walk through a timeline of the past two years, showing JRuby's open-source evolution step by step.

event.title: KDE Group Photo
event.abstract: Group photo of the KDE and GNOME people.
event.description: There will be a group photo of the KDE people before the actual devroom talks start. Weather permitting, we'll try to take the picture outside, next to the KDE room. In case of rain, we'll try to find some other location in the neighbourhood. Be on time near the devroom and follow us to whatever location we'll use. After the KDE photo, we'll also take a group photo together with the GNOME people.

event.title: A Look at KOffice 2 and ODF
event.abstract: KOffice 2.0 is going to be released soon. This talk will start with an overview of the main features this new release will have (such as the lightweight Flake objects, and color management through Pigment), and will then will go into some more detail about the use of ODF in KOffice.
event.description:
Most of the [[http:koffice.kde.org KOffice Suite] has been rewritten or at least refactored since the 1.6 series. For example, we introduced the Flake framework, enabling easy sharing of components such as vector drawings and text shapes throughout the whole range of [[http://koffice.kde.org KOffice applications].

The aim of this talk is to discover how this new suite is organized, the main changes, and its relation with ODF.

event.title: Roadmap for multiplayer gaming in KDE 4
event.abstract: KDE 4.0 introduced native GGZ client libraries for automatic online game framework integration for the first time. In the coming versions, this will be extended to KDE-based game servers and game launchers to reach the goal of free, privacy-respecting and diversified player communities.
event.description:
In KDE 2.x and 3.0 times, some support for network gaming was provided through libkdegames. In the meantime, the cross-desktop GGZ Gaming Zone project was working hard on a dedicated infrastructure for online games and communities, including support of APIs for development in C, C++, Python and Ruby.

In order to reach the developers of the respective toolkits better, most of GGZ's KDE code is not only ported to KDE 4.x but also fused into libkdegames to let it develop progressively together with the KDE codebase. At the moment, this includes some helper code for low-level networking (libkggznet) as well as the usual Qt-style easy connection of game clients to the gaming zone.

Now that the KDE 4.1 development cycle has started, a matching Qt-style server library (libkggzdmod) will be introduced in addition to the existing pure C++ ggzdmod++ so that KDE developers can share code between client and server without having to redesign. In addition, the main GGZ application for KDE 3, called KGGZ, will be ported. It has been a chat client with the ability to launch games and watch statistics. Due to increasing popularity of Jabber and similar networks, integration with Kopete will be discussed in the talk as well, so that the GGZ developers can focus on what they're good at: making multiplayer just work.

event.title: Nepomuk
event.abstract: Nepomuk - The Road to a Semantic KDE Desktop
event.description:
Semantic KDE has as main goal the application of one the visions of the Social Semantic Desktop paradigm, i.e. to create a seamless communication channel between different applications present on the desktop as well as between applications used by one person on their desktop to applications used by another person on another desktop.

Semantic KDE provides a solution to the data interoperability issue by making use of formal ontologies, able to capture both a shared conceptualization of desktop data and personal mental models and more specific, of RDF (Resource Description Format), as a common data representation format.

Last, but not least, Semantic KDE will build semantic and social technologies that can be integrated deeply into the KDE framework and provide a basis for Semantic KDE applications.

event.title: KDE on Windows
event.abstract: This talk will give an overview about what has been achieved wrt. KDE on Windows and what can be expected in the future. It will also explain how we do the developments under Windows, which things are similar to Unix, which things are different, and how people can start to hack on KDE on Windows.
event.description:
In the talk you will see how simple it is for end-users to install KDE on Windows. Some known KDE programs will be shown in action and compared to their windows counterparts. Then we will look at our development process, and how we had to adapt that to the new Windows platform.

We will see which major problems we were facing, and how they were solved, and we will have a look at the remaining problems, which still have to be fixed.

In the last part we will explain how our staging and distribution infrastructure for the KDE binary packages under Windows works, and we will give a hands-on introduction into compiling KDE programs on windows by your own.

event.title: Free software in Telecom focusing on Qtopia
event.abstract: Community Manager Knut Yrvin at Trolltech will present mobile phone programming with Qtopia on Greenphone and Neo 1973.
event.description: He will focus on game programming and Telenors Program for Advanced Telecom Services, developing free software for phones. Trolltech ASA has a research and innovation program with Telenor. Telenor is an international wireless carrier with 135 million customers world wide. This is a more general speak for everyone.

event.title: Welcome
event.abstract: Welcome to the KDE Developer Room at FOSDEM 2008.
event.description: Opening of the KDE Developer Room.

event.title: How a large scale opensource project works
event.abstract: How the FreeBSD Project Works
event.description:
The FreeBSD Project is one of the oldest and most successful open source operating system projects, seeing wide deployment across the IT industry. From the root name servers, to top tier ISPs, to core router operating systems, to firewalls, to embedded appliances, you can't use a networked computer for ten minutes without using FreeBSD dozens of times.

Part of FreeBSD's reputation for quality and reliability comes from the nature of its development organization -- driven by a hundreds of highly skilled volunteers, from high school students to university professors. And unlike most open source projects, the FreeBSD Project has developers who have been working on the same source base for over twenty years.

But how does this organization work? Who pays the bandwidth bills, runs the web servers, writes the documentation, writes the code, and calls the shots? And how can developers in a dozen time zones reach agreement on the time of day, let alone a kernel architecture?

This presentation will attempt to provide, in 45 minutes, a brief if entertaining snapshot into what makes FreeBSD run.

event.title: LPI exam session 1
event.abstract: LPI exam session #1

event.title: LPI exam session 2
event.abstract: LPI exam session #2

event.title: LPI 2008 - a certification passage
event.abstract: A summary of the existing LPIC program and what is planned as the next steps.

event.title: Calendar Project
event.abstract:
Calendar Project: Status, Strategy & QA.

The first part of the talk will center about the current state of the project (recent accomplishments and releases) and will give a glimpse of what's coming in the next 6-12 months. In the second part we will shed some light on the QA efforts in such a small project.
event.description:
With 4 releases in the last 16 months and the next release (0.8) just around the corner, the talk will first focus on the current highlights of the project and the issues that it is currently facing. It will then present some highlights from the upcoming release and give a glimpse of what's coming up on the road to 1.0. The first part of the talk will end with a short strategic outlook.

The second part will give an overview of the QA activites in the Mozilla Calendar project. Challenges for a community project, calendar client, and Mozilla platform application. Testing techniques ranging from unscripted to automated, and how practices and frameworks provided by the Mozilla platform can help.

event.title: Mozilla Calendar Workshop
event.abstract: Philipp will be holding a hands-on workshop aims at encouraging developers to participate in the Mozilla Calendar Project either as an extension developer or even more. This could be of interest for you if you've always wanted to make an extension for Mozilla Sunbird or Lightning but have never had the time to dive in.

event.title: Mozilla Europe
event.abstract: General Introductions followed by an update on the work of Mozilla Europe.
event.description: Introduction to the Mozilla meeting at Fosdem, '08 and general Mozilla update.

event.title: Mozilla Labs Weave
event.abstract: Discussion around ideas and plans for building and scaling a community-based innovation lab; and details on major projects and initiatives such as Weave.

event.title: Songbird
event.abstract: Got a website? Want richer media-interaction experiences with your end users? Or do you just want to create the next cool media web mashup? Songbird, a desktop media player powered by Mozilla's XULRunner platform, makes connecting any device to any website as simple as HTML & Javascript. Develop either server side webapps, or client side extensions (like Firefox!) to create media web mashups.
event.description:
Yawn... another day, another media player. Yes and no. Songbird is a web player, integrating a media player with all the goodness of Mozilla browser technology. Songbird has an entirely new and unique set of features and APIs that support the burdgeoning movement to free up media on the web, eliminating those annoying vertical media silos and allowing users to have more interactive and rich media experiences with the web.

This session will explore Songbird, its APIs, and existing cool media web mashups that break out beyond the traditional media player fold. We'll show how simple it is to start developing a website to utilize Songbird's API to dynamically interact with a user's media library.

By building on top of one of the best and most extensible open source web browsers out there, Songbird has made it easy for web developers to easily integrate their sites into an end user's desktop media player experience. By leveraging extensions or Songbird Widgets composed of simple plain old HTML and Javascript, developers can create awesome media web mashups that extend the user's media player beyond just the desktop. Websites (such as, but not limited to music stores and music blogs) can take advantage of Songbird's remote Webpage API to allow for seamless integration all the way from the website to the desktop media player to the portable music device.

event.title: Project SUMO (Firefox Support)
event.abstract: SUMO is short for support.mozilla.com, Mozilla's new user-to-user support channel for Firefox, consisting of an extensive knowledge base, a support forum, and the ability to ask questions directly to more experienced Firefox users in live chat sessions. This session covers the background of the project, as well as the recent progress and the plans for the future.
event.description: Since SUMO is a community-driven project, we really need your help! There are lots of things that can be done, such as writing articles, filing article requests, translating articles to your native language, answering questions in the forum, or helping users using live chat.

event.title: Thunderbird
event.abstract: Status and Future Plans

event.title: /etc/init.d/olpc_europe start
event.abstract:
During the last 12 months many OLPC grassroots initiatives in Europe and elsewhere in the world popped up, to promote the OLPC idea locally in their communities, to help children locally and globally.

OLPC Europe aims to be a focus point to share experiences, ideas and work between those local groups and towards the global OLPC project. Like the global project we aim to be an education project and use that laptop as a means.
event.description:
This meeting aims to get the different people from any OLPC related initiative together, to get us know each other and to discuss the feature of the young OLPC Europe project.

If you intend to participate please enter yourself at http://wiki.laptop.org/go/OLPC_Europe/Events/FOSDEM

event.title: OOo 3: Shattered and Resurrected
event.abstract: For the higher good of modularity and extensibility the OpenOffice.org suite will change from a big monolith to a nice and clean multi-layer stack in OOo 3. Not only conceptually, but also represented in the installation's layout on the hard drive. This presentation will examine OpenOffice.org's modularization effort.
event.description:
Modularization has a number of consequences for the existing code. Code and data has to be sorted into the various layers. Code at one layer needs to find code and data at other layers. And despite all those separate layers, the end user still wants an installation and update experience that just works, in one click. Also, of course, the resulting code base should please, please be way easier to build and maintain...

Lots of work, lots of opportunities to break things (especially in arcane scenarios) -- lots of opportunities for YOU to help keep OOo up and running on your favorite platform! Stephan will present the technical difficulties he faced, how his team solved them on the various platforms supported by OOo, and how other products could benefit from what they have learned along the way. This will hopefully spark some lively discussions, so come and participate!

event.title: Where's OOo's UI abstraction heading for?
event.abstract: A discussion on GSL future plans in light of recent events like the new UI layout effort, Aqua porting issues, and the UNO canvas layer.
event.description:
OOo's GSL project, with its main entity VCL, abstracts the platform GUI into a set of classes and services (for windows, buttons, dialogs, interfaces to render graphics etc.).

This abstraction has encountered some challenges in the past, the last one being the MacOS Aqua port, because this platform looks and feels significantly different to break quite a few assumptions made.

For OOo to stay competitive, gsl needs to evolve in several areas, most urgently needed are:

  • a graphic rendering facility that does antialiasing, supports alpha blending for all operations, can handle sub-pixel coordinates and can be easily mapped to contemporary graphics hardware
  • retire the old, pixel-based, fixed dialog designs, in favor of a more descriptive, auto-layouting dialog facility
  • not only use the platform look (by having the underlying platform UI subsystem render the buttons), but also the feel - that means, use native platform controls wherever possible
The first two points are currently tackled, the former with the XCanvas UNO API, the latter with the XML layout CWS. The last item probably requires the most effort, because large parts of the code rely on specific behaviour of the current, hard-coded VCL control logic. The talk will present the work already done, give an outlook for the planned enhancements of OOo 3.0, and will sketch a long-term transition plan towards the mentioned goals.

event.title: OpenOffice.org programmability - at a glance
event.abstract: This session will give a detailed overview about the programmability features of OpenOffice.org that is more than a standalone office suite. The session will explain how developers can program with or for OpenOffice.org.
event.description:
The popularity of the standardized (OASIS and ISO/IEC 26300) Open Document Format for Office Applications (OpenDocument) is growing. This also drives the popularity of OpenOffice.org in government agencies and enterprises. Corporate users often demand the integration of office productivity into existing workflows and applications. They also often require additional functionality or special customizations of the existing features.

OpenOffice.org offers a language independent application programming interface (API) which allows to program OpenOffice.org in various supported programming languages. It allows to use OpenOffice.org as service provider in other applications, extend it with new functionality or simply customize and control OpenOffice.org

Typical use cases are document creation, conversion or printing from remote client applications (typical server scenarios). Embedding office functionality into own Java applications to make use of the rich feature set. For example using the editor of the word processor application with all its features in your own application. Or intercept and replace existing commands with own implementations. For example replace the standard save/load commands to save/load directly into/from a document management system (DMS). Alternatively it is possible to insert special save/load menu entries to support the DMS additionally. Do you have thought about embedding your own Java component into an OpenOffice.org writer document? Embed Java components and activate them outplace in an external window. The list of use cases can be extended easily and even popular is the development of extensions for OpenOffice.org like Firefox Add-ons, see for example the growing OpenOffice.org extensions repository.

In detail the session will cover the following:

  • Introduction into UNO (Universal Network Objects)
  • API concepts and design patterns
  • Introduction into extensions
  • Examples of special Service Provider Interfaces

event.title: Looking ahead to openSUSE 11.0
event.abstract: openSUSE 11.0 will be the next openSUSE distribution release. We like to discuss what major features will be in it and how to deliver a stable with lots of new software.

event.title: The openSUSE Base System
event.abstract: Stripping openSUSE down to a bare minimal system for bootstrapping, cross-building and fast deployment on small systems.

event.title: openSUSE Build Service Overview
event.abstract: Introduction into the openSUSE Build Service, why it was created, what are the goals it wants to achieve and a brief overview about its components.

event.title: Linkat: a distribution based on SUSE for the schools, community and services around it
event.abstract: Linkat: openSUSE based distribution for the schools, community and services around it.
event.description:
We will present Linkat, a Linux distribution that is based on SLED10 but also has openSUSE packages as well as from other repositories, and its relation with the openSUSE community.

We will present it from different perspectives: technical perspective, business perspective, local community perspective and international community perspective. We will see how all these views are interrelated in a local ecosystem that is possible thanks to linkat.

Finally we'll discuss future plans and future collaborations with the openSUSE community through the openSUSE BuildService.

event.title: Build Service Web Interface

We will talk about the following topics:

event.title: Perl 6
event.abstract: Patrick Michaud will talk about the Perl 6 programming language from a variety of perspectives, and targeting a number of different audiences.
event.description:
Patrick will look at some of the changes and improvements that Perl 6 has made as a language over previous versions of Perl, as well as many of the technical details of its implementation.

Along the way he'll also take a look at Parrot, and see how it is progressing to become a common runtime platform for Perl, Python, PHP, Ruby, Javascript, and many other dynamic languages.

event.title: Status update of Software Patents
event.abstract: Status update on software patents in Europe.
event.description:
Pieter Hintjens, past president of the FFII will give us an update on the current state of things regarding software patents in Europe.

He'll speak about the politicization of open standards and software patents, and where we stand in the two wars we're fighting, one at the international level (OOXML hits ISO) and one in Europe (software patents).

event.title: Tux with Shades, Linux in Hollywood
event.abstract:
Gabrielle Pantera and Robin Rowe will talk about Linux in the motion picture industry, especially its use at the major studios. This community is an upside-down parallel universe where Linux is everywhere, and Windows and Mac are niche operating systems. They'll talk about how the movie Titanic touched off a mass migration to Linux, what Linux tools are used and how. The result is virtually every blockbuster or animated feature in theaters today is made using Linux tools.

Some movie clips will be screened to show technically and visually how Linux has become the #1 operating system for making blockbuster films, and implications for the future will be discussed.
event.description:
At first, studios had no choice but to develop Linux applications in-house. The film industry has millions of lines of Linux code, both desktop applications and server pipelines. Studio Linux programmers write code in C++, Python, Perl, and Java. What does all this secret proprietary Linux code do? And, why do they do parallel programming with grid computing? How does the film industry use renderfarms with thousands of CPUs?

Studios no longer have to develop their own tools. They can buy the Linux tools they need off the shelf. Commercial Linux motion picture tools available today include Combustion, FrameCycler, Houdini, Maya, Mental Ray, Nuke, Piranha, Platform LXF, RaveHD, RenderMan, SoftImage|XSI and more. What are all these tools for and where did they come from? What do they cost? How did a vibrant commercial Linux applications market emerge in this industry, and why nowhere else?

The film industry has funded open source development. CinePaint, Wine, and FLTK are open source projects that have received financial support from the film industry in the past. FLTK was developed at Digital Domain to support their proprietary application development and then released as LGPL. What kind of crazy open source world is this where copyright zealot Disney funds development of LGPL code in Wine to replace Windows? Why isn't the film industry doing more to support open source development?

event.title: Unicoding With PHP 6
event.abstract: The Unicode support is the #1 feature in PHP 6. Come to this session and find out what this means for you and how you can take advantage of it.
event.description:
Don't be left behind as the software world moves towards language and cultural sensitivity. Speaking Unicode is all the rage these days and this session will show what PHP has learned and how easy it will be to work with multilingual text.

This talk will provide an overview of the most salient features of the Unicode support and illustrate the new internationalization features with a variety of demos on topics such as: * Character set conversion * Text boundary analysis * Working with international dates and calendars * Transliteration and text normalization * Working with character sets and properties

event.title: Welcome
event.abstract: FOSDEM Opening Talk
event.description: The FOSDEM Opening Talk, including the infamous FOSDEM dance.

event.title: Nouveau: Cooking an open source driver
event.abstract: Cooking a graphics driver involves a complex recipe and a number of ingredients. This talk will detail the recipe used for Nouveau, an open source 2D/3D nVidia driver.
event.description:
We will focus on the required steps to get a nice meal, including 2D acceleration with EXA, 3D acceleration support using gallium, proper modesetting with dual head, improved Xv support, and what all this entails. Less technical aspects like building a community around a driver will also be discussed.

We will finish by discussing future cooking, including moving more of the driver components into the kernel and possible extensions like fb support.

event.title: Open sourcing ATI
event.abstract: In 2007, AMD committed itself to providing open source support for its ATI range of GPUs. In september this was kicked off by releasing initial documentation for its R500 and R600 class devices. This unprecedented move has taken the free software graphics world by storm and was followed by subsequent documentation and information releases.
event.description: This talk will outline AMDs intentions and future plans, but will also discuss the difficulties encountered when turning a large graphic card maker into an open source shop.

event.title: The RadeonHD project
event.abstract: RadeonHD is the project around the driver for the ATI Radeon R5xx/RS6xx/R6xx video chipsets funded and supported by AMD. This driver is developed by a group of open source developers involving some engineers from SUSE. Since its inception 6 month ago this project has grown rapidly and has acquired a large user community.
event.description: This talk will illustrate some of the RadeonHD projects history, it's current status, its roadmap and future developments.

event.title: Xen
event.abstract: Ian speaks about the factors that are making ubiquitous virtualization possible, as well as its advantages.
event.description:
Hypervisors are set to become ubiquitous on PC hardware, built-in to every server, and ultimately, every laptop too.

The open source Xen hypervisor is at the forefront of this movement, its architecture making it ideally suited for embedding in firmware and providing highly secure and efficient virtualization.

This talk looks at the hardware and software factors that are making ubiquitous virtualization possible, and discusses the benefits that virtualization brings to both data centres and personal computing devices.

Pratt will give a status update of the Xen project, and talk about some of the cool new things that are on the roadmap.

event.title: VirtualBox
event.abstract: VirtualBox is a feature rich and powerful virtualization platform available for Linux, Windows, Mac OS, Solaris and other platforms.
event.description:
This talk starts with an overview of the product and shows the architecture and how it compares to other commercial and open solutions on the market.

Advanced virtualization topics such as hardware extensions and future trends and development will also be discussed.

event.title: CakePHP
event.abstract: This session will introduce the latest version of the CakePHP framework.
event.description:
CakePHP is a rapid development framework for PHP, which derives principles from Ruby on Rails, and has since become a popular choice for building web applications.

We will start by looking at some of these principles behind CakePHP and continue by looking deeply into a CakePHP application. We will see how CakePHP reduces the amount of maintainable lines of code, while providing a robust and extensible architecture to handle the features needed for a web application.

With this knowledge, we can look at some of the more advanced features of CakePHP that make developers lives easier with simple approaches to common web application problems. Some of the features to be reviewed include the Bake command line code generation tool, application scaffolding, association data mapping, API services.

The talk will also share some of the history, heritage, and goals of the project.

Attend this talk to see why over 6500 developers have joined the CakePHP google group.

event.title: Conary Packaging: Simply Powerful
event.abstract: Conary has a powerful set of tools for package building that make packaging easy -- not just compiling, but maintaining, updating, and testing.
event.description:
Michael will present http://wiki.rpath.com/wiki/Conary Conary] packaging, first demonstrating how simple the process is, then providing technical details of features that make packaging a simple, easy, repeatable process.

He will show how Conary handles common cases automatically, while making it easy to override its defaults for unusual cases.

Michael will also demonstrate how Conary improves packaging quality, by making packaging consistent and by providing tools to analyze packages and collections of packages.

Last but not least, he will explain how Conary's dependency management is different from legacy package management, encoding more thorough dependency information without requiring cascading piles of irrelevant packages.

event.title: Hudson
event.abstract: Kohsuke Kawaguchi talks about Hudson, a continuous integration system that he's been developing for the last few years. It is a web application that continuously builds your project and keeps track of what's happening.
event.description:
A part of the talk will be about the general introduction of it and what it can do. A demo will be shown, and a highlight of most interesting technologies behind Hudson.

These include the plugin system, the remoting infrastructure, the way distributed builds are handled, how installation is simplified, and the avoidance of cryptic URLs in a very REST-full web application.

event.title: SCons
event.abstract: This talk discusses use of the SCons build system for Open Source projects.
event.description:
SCons is a cross-platform software build system with a domain-specific configuration language implemented in Python, which provides the ability to configure builds with an expressive scripting language instead of static dependency definitions.

SCons emphasizes a whole-tree approach to managing the software dependency graph, including the ability to handle difficult configurations like automatically discovering dependencies in generated header files. SCons also contains integrated support for software packaging and Autoconf-like system configuration.

SCons is backed by a strong test-driven development methodology (lines of test code outnumber source code by about 2.4 to 1) to ensure the quality of contributions from more than 150 developers since the project's inception. The result is a software build tool with enough reliability and consistency for large-scale enterprise software builds.

This talk will walk through various best practices for configuring Open Source projects using SCons, including limitations and pitfalls to avoid.

event.title: CMake
event.abstract: This talk is about the CMake build system.
event.description:
CMake is a cross platform build system supporting Windows, Linux, UNIX, and Mac OSX platforms. Unlike other build system, CMake generates projects using the native build tools like KDevelop, Visual Studio, makefiles, and Xcode.

This allows developers to use the tools they are most productive with. In addition to building software, CMake provides a testing system called CTest, and a packaging system called CPack.

This talk will cover how to build, package and test software with the CMake family of tools.

event.title: PackageKit
event.abstract: The presentation will give a complete overview of PackageKit along with background material.
event.description:
The presentation will first highlight the issues that need solving, and expose the problems we have in the current suite of tools. It will examine other update solutions such as Microsoft Windows Vista (tm), Apple Mac OS X (tm) and also what has been done with some Linux distributions.

The main section of the talk will introduce PackageKit, expose the internal design and explain any important ideas and design choices.

Finally, ways to use PackageKit are discussed, along with screenshots of all the latest GUI tools. Time will remain for questions and discussion about PackageKit at the end.

PackageKit is a system designed to make installing and updating software on your computer easier. The primary design goal is to unify all the software graphical tools used in different distributions, and use some of the latest technology like PolicyKit to make the process suck less.

Use cases for PackageKit exist for the following scenarios:

  • Boot time security updates
  • Installing files automatically, e.g. openoffice-clipart
  • Installing software required for new hardware, e.g. smart-card readers
  • Allowing unprivileged users to install software in a corporate build
  • Opening unknown file formats
Formally, PackageKit is a D-Bus abstraction layer that allows the session user to manage packages in a secure way using a cross-distro, cross-architecture API.

event.title: openQRM, pluggable virtualization for modern data-centers
event.abstract: This presentation deals with the pluggable virtualization architecture of openQRM and describes how to conform and automate deployment, management, maintenance and migration of physical systems and virtual machines seamlessly. It provides an detailed overview about the openQRM virtualization plugins and their integration within the data-center management platform.
event.description:
To ease up the management and maintenance of modern data-centers the current evolution of virtualization technologies directs system administrators more and more to virtual server appliances. One of the goals is a server-Image based deployment including and automated resource management plus the possibility to easy migrate physical systems to virtual machines (P2V). Other targets are the option to move from one virtualization type to a different one (V2V) to avoid vendor-locks by bounding a complete data-center to a single virtualization technology and also the support for migrating virtual appliances back to physical systems (V2P).

To conform with current mainstream virtualization technologies, e.g. VMware, Xen, Qemu and Linux-VServer, openQRM provides a generic virtualization layer, the “partition-bridge”. Via a well-defined API the openQRM virtualization plugins are interfacing with this “partition-bridge” to unify the resource management by adding additional virtual resources from the type “partition”.
