As the result in openQRM virtual machines are managed in the same way as physical systems and the system administrator may decide at any time to run a specific server-image on real hardware, move it to a VMware partition, from there to a Xen partition and back to a real, physical existing server without any changes on the server-Image itself nor hassling with the different virtualization configuration files..

This presentation deals with the pluggable virtualization architecture of openQRM and describes how to conform and automate deployment, management, maintenance and migration of physical systems and virtual machines seamlessly. It provides an detailed overview about the openQRM virtualization plugins and their integration within the data-center management platform.

event.title: Application virtualization with next-generation Klik
event.abstract: The talk will start with a short live demonstration of klik2 and then proceed into the technical aspects of creating a format and implementation for providing cross-distro application images.
event.description:
Klik is all about virtualization on the application level.

We are all familiar with virtualization at the operating system or PC hardware level. klik applies the same idea to a different level: namely the level of individual applications.

Klik creates applications that are encapsulated into a single file. This file in fact is a compressed file system image similar to the ISO image format that we know from burning data CDs. Hence, klik is the implementation of the ''"1 application == 1 file"'' principle.

While this might sound complicated, the idea is really very easy: Take an application and put it together with everything (libraries, icons, data files, configuration files, man pages, manuals and other resources) it needs for successful execution into an ISO image, from which you can run it. You can then easily move the file, take it with you on a USB stick, send it to a friend.

Your application will run on any major distribution, without the need for an installation as we know it. That's the basic idea, but implementation isn't trivial, as will be discussed in the talk. After a brief live demonstration, Pfeiffle and Peter will dive into the technical details of the upcoming implementation code-named "klik2".

event.title: CloudBridges: bridging social networks
event.abstract: The talk will explain the underlying technology of Google's OpenSocial platform, and the philosophy of DataPortability, then give an example of friending between two social network accounts via CloudBridges. The future potential of a fully open, Social Web will be explored.
event.description: A CloudBridge is a small FOSS application you can install into your profile on a social network which provides you with a microformat-based profile on the open Web, with a controllable level of privacy. It lets you specify which friends can see your profile, even if those friends are on a different social network. As such it is the first public example of a meta social network, where people from different networks can friend each other without having to create any new accounts.

event.title: KeySigning Party
event.abstract: GPG/PGP and CAcert keysigning party
event.description: See http://fosdem.org/2008/keysigning for details.

event.title: Sepia: metadata based file browser
event.abstract:
In my Talk, I plan to:

  • give a general overview of the project,
  • show how you can create a music folder and define some virtual folders and
  • explain the sparse folder tree for navigation.
event.description: (Meta) Sepia is a new file browser that adapts to the current folder and makes heavy use of metadata. It integrates features like (mass) tagging, virtual folders, metadata search and directory/file-specific views and actions. These features are all well known from domain specific file browsers like F-Spot or Amarok and are now usable for all files. While designing the user interface, I developed a new navigational widget: the sparse folder tree. It displays places, where you will likely want to go to next and presents them in a tree. It replaces the normal folder tree with expanders, the history, the places sidebar, bookmarks and the button-based location bar, like they all exist in nautilus. It turned out to be very useful and I described it in my blog at http://p4n.net. (Meta) Sepia is written in Ruby with Ruby-GNOME2 and uses (Meta) Tracker as indexing backend and metadata storage. Just recently, I switched from Qt to Gtk and I havn't finished all features yet. So, the program is still to be considered alpha and there is plenty of bugfixing and polishing to do. I hope to get a beta version out before FOSSDEM'08.

event.title: Ganeti: virtual cluster management tool
event.abstract: I'll give a quick introduction about what Ganeti is and who can benefit by using it, and then proceed with a fast update on the development of version 1.3.
event.description: Ganeti is a virtual cluster management tool

event.title: View-OS: partial virtualisation
event.abstract: In View-OS each process can have its own view of the executing environment, e.g. its own file system view, networking configuration etc. This talk presents the structure and some applications of a GNU/Linux implementation of View-OS, named *MView, along with a quick overview of other tools from the Virtual Square project.
event.description: Almost every modern OS gives all processes the same "global view" on their execution environment (network interfaces and addresses, file system hierarchy, time, set of devices etc.). Even if some resources are hidden or protected, a name usually means the same resource for everyone. View-OS lets regular users negate this "global view assumption" for their own processes. It has been implemented as two different versions: UMView and KMView (or *MView for short). UMView is a partial virtual machine running on a standard Linux kernel and supporting standard GNU/Linux binaries. KMView is faster, but needs a utrace capable kernel and a specific kernel module. Specific modules allow to give processes specific views on various classes of resources. If there's no need for a personal view on a resource, *MView lets the Linux kernel directly manage it.

event.title: Hildon App. Manager: package management for Internet Tablets
event.abstract:
Debian-style package management for maemo consumers

- For applications, for the operating system. - For hackers, for grandmas (and hacking grandmas). - Challenge: easy and robust configuration management on the device. - Challenge: traditional monolithic development and release process for mobile devices: OS as binary blob, no dependencies between applications.

Our approaches to the challenges will be explained briefly.
event.description:
The Hildon Application Manager is pre-installed on all Internet Tablets and handles the installation and removal of additional software. In the future, it will also keep the operating system itself up-to-date.

The Application Manager is a frontend to apt and dpkg, like Synaptic or gnome-app-install, only different.

event.title: Foresight Linux: a new paradigm in distro making
event.abstract:
o 'traditionally' there were no 'binary based' rolling distributions, for a reason.

The idea is to show how that is - with the right tools - not only possible, but in fact can change completely what to expect from a linux distribution.

The point is not to do a conary/rMake/foresight infomercial, but to present a new paradigm in distro making (Foresight Linux 2 (expected H1/2008)), the challenges we face(d), etc.
event.description: o Foresight Linux is a next generation linux distribution built around conary and rMake. o Currently released version (1.x train) has a very strong Gnome focus, and next version will have KDE and XFCE editions too. o Used as the base of the Official Gnome Development Kit.

event.title: Polippix: free software to protect basic rights and freedoms
event.abstract: How to use free software to protect basic rights and freedoms. Rigts and freedoms that are not traditionally viewed as IT-relatd, but is now very dependent on IT either because everything is becoming digital or because IT is used to take away freedoms: Anonymity, privacy, exchange of information (anti infosoc/trusted computing), freedom to innovate (anti patent), etc. Free software is necessary to achieve these freedoms. I believe that it is necessary to make use of these freedoms to not lose them for real. The Polippix project has demonstrated the political influence free software can have when it is put to use. We managed to get the attention of every major TV-station and newspaper in Denmark and it make some politicians listen to us. People and organizations from European countries and less democratic countries have show interest in Polippix and the upcoming version 2 will be internationally oriented.
event.description: It is a live CD, based on Knoppix (next version is based on Kubuntu)

event.title: tangoGPS: from Gtk development to Openmoko app.
event.abstract: The interesting part of the app is the fact that it is entirely developed on a desktop machine set up for GNOME development without anything special and the resulting app simply needs to be recompiled in order to run under OpenMoko on the FIC Neo1973 phone. The talk will thus focus on the ease with which any Gtk-developer can develop for Openmoko literally in minutes.
event.description: Current Project Version: 0.1, fully functional, loading automatically maps from OpenStreetMaps and displaying them, plus location cursor and track.

event.title: Wir3D: visual network scanner
event.abstract: My lightning talk will mainly cover the subject of network topology maps. I'll explain why the currently available solutions are insufficient in some cases and what are the advantages of drawing 3D topology maps. I'll also mention about NMS apps: Graphical UI vs. Web UI and the idea of using 3D topology maps to create a highly intuitive UI for NMS.
event.description: WiR3D is a SNMP network scanner which uses LANout to visualise the scanning results in a 3D scene. In the future more features will be added including GTK GUI, monitoring and alerting, so the program will become NMS. Here's the link to the short movie at YouTube showing WiR3D in action: http://youtube.com/watch?v=SOMvVxcihN8

event.title: K-3D: 3D modeling and animation package
event.abstract: My presentation will give a brief overview of the K-3D architecture, and show how to write and use a simple plugin. The idea is to demonstrate how easy it is to write a plugin, and how the visual programming system allows any plugin to immediately work together with the rest of K-3D to allow new, powerful combinations. Hopefully, this will be convincing enough to attract new developers.
event.description: K-3D is a free 3D modeling and animation package, written by Timothy M. Shead, who released the project under the GPL in 1999. The main features that set K-3D apart from other FOSS modelers are its object-oriented design, its "visual programming" system and the extremely modular architecture. A solid framework and many modeling tools are currently in place, as well as support for several external rendering engines. K-3D also participated in the Google Summer of Code 2007 with two students, one of whom successfully finished his project.

event.title: MySQL Proxy: monitor, analyze and transform queries
event.abstract: Using MySQL Proxy for scale out, tracking queries, modifying and denying SQL. All controlled by a LUA script, transparent to the application and with as little latency as possible.
event.description: MySQL Proxy is a simple program that sits between your client and MySQL server(s) that can monitor, analyze or transform their communication. Its flexibility allows for unlimited uses; common ones include: load balancing; failover; query analysis; query filtering and modification; and many more.

event.title: Archetype: structural JavaScript Framework
event.abstract: My talk will present why we have made Archetype Javascript Framework, by comparing serverside and clientside ways to work, and what it does to do more with much of the same (JavaScript).
event.description:
Archetype is a structural JavaScript Framework (just like no other JS Framework). It helps a lot in big JavaScript development fo Ajax applications, and able developers to use JS instead of Flash for heavy developments.

The Framework:

  • simplifies good practices in JS
  • is modular (can be used just for some of its function : loading,
templates, logging, etc.)
  • is designed to fully work in MVC on the client side
  • provide an easy to use logging interface
  • adds a lightning fast template system for JS inspired by Smarty
  • help for files loading in an efficient way (JS dependencies, templates,
etc.) to avoid JS loading errors in big projects
  • adds communication through Events between components
  • ease development through :
- Components (a component is based on a JS Object like definition, defining dependencies, libraries and services it uses, and of course, it's methods and variables. It's kind of a "super-object") - Graphical components (aka your own widgets, with template and css loading) - Method Builders for Components (Archetype associates a particular service to a method call, based on the method name) Archetype simplifies much of JS uncommon behavior compared to common languages (java, php, etc.): you don't need to program exactly what you want, you just need to describe it and Archetype will write it as needed !

event.title: Ajatus: offline Ajax-driven P2P CRM app
event.abstract: The talk will introduce the Ajatus project and application, show how data can be extended and connected by tagging, and how it can be synchronized between multiple users and machines.
event.description:
Ajatus is an offline Ajax-driven P2P CRM application for free software consultants and web workers. It enables users to manage their billable hours, expenses, meeting notes and contacts in a consistent workstream, and keep those synchronized between multiple machines and with their clients and partners. With replication the data can be carried on trips with a Linux tablet, and kept at the same time accessible over the web.

The Ajatus project is GPLd, community-driven free software project built on CouchDb and jQuery, and managed over a collaborative Git repository. Hackers can extend the system with virtually any language through the RESTful plugin API.

Ajatus can be run on any platform CouchDb/Erlang and a modern web browser is available for. Implementations include Linux and OS X laptops, maemo-based internet tablets and the OLPC.

event.title: Minerva: house automation suite
event.abstract: The talk will cover the architecture necessary to run a house through software, the ubiquitous web browser, and the issues involved in this hitherto uncharted field. It will also detail the basic abstractions in the house automation field, showing how Minerva lets you control the systems currently supported, and how new 'conduits' can be added. A quick run-through of various features will follow. There should also be the time to cover the subtleties of home automation.
event.description: Minerva is a complete, easy to use, home automation suite. Using Minerva you can make your home easier and cheaper to run and more secure. With Minerva you can: switch on your lights from anywhere, using a mobile phone or PC; email your video; check your security CCTV footage; control your central heating and much more. It runs on GNU/Linux, but exists in its own mini eco-system, with its own list of users, set of scripts, and functionality. It relies on command line tools to perform all of its many tasks, and can therefore be run from virtually any platform (smartphone, PDA, laptop or remote PC) with identical functionality. Minerva's visionary grand design is to provide a means whereby every piece of home technology can be interfaced together through common and Open technology - and that technology is Minerva!

event.title: BluePad: from cell phone to remote bluetooth controller
event.abstract: I will talk about BluePad, explaining how it works (Python, java, BlueZ and Uinput kernel module) and give a short demonstration of the project.
event.description: BluePad turns a cell phone into a remote bluetooth controller with which you can control your computer. It is free software released under GNU GPL license. It is composed by two programs, one for you to install in your computer, and another for you to install in a mobile device.

event.title: Coherence: a DLNA/UPnP framework
event.abstract:
So my talk would be about adding UPnP functionality to Rhythmbox - what does this mean, what Rhythmbox can do more after that. What we learned from the interaction with a before "isolated" application.

And what's needed for other digital media related Linux software to take part as a server and/or a client in the UPnP world.
event.description:
UPnP A/V, and DLNA especially, is a set of specifications to define interoperability between digital media sharing devices, like MediaServers and MediaRenderers/-Players.

Coherence is used (embedded) in Elisa [elisa.fluendo.com] and since a few months in Rhythmbox [www.rhythmbox.org] too. On itself it can act as a standalone MediaServer or a GStreamer based MediaRenderer.

I've finished these days the next plugin for Rhythmbox, let it now act as an UPnP MediaRenderer too, controlled by an UPnP ControlPoint, e.g a Nokia N800 or a N95.

http://netzflocken.de/2008/01/30/coherence-and-rhythmbox-upnp-interaction

event.title: GGZ Gaming Zone: Multiplayer gaming framework
event.abstract: Contents of the talk: «Multiplayer gaming through GGZ» While many games make use of 3D engines, sound libraries or physics simulators, programmers are often wasting time by writing all the networking aspects of games by themselves. The GGZ Gaming Zone, which was founded in the year 2000 initially to offer a few games for online play, has since turned into a provider of powerful libraries which relieve the programmers of those tasks. Integrating GGZ into games is easier than ever thanks to the new toolkit-aware integration libraries. The talk will highlight some examples and also of the challenges of expanding free gaming on the internet.
event.description: GGZ Gaming Zone unifies multiplayer capabilities of free games at the technical level, while diversifying it on the level of experience by offering many cool add-ons to the core game server infrastructure. GGZ powers the KDE and GNOME multiplayer frameworks, and is used by Freeciv and other games as well.

event.title: Mamona: completely open source SDK for Maemo
event.abstract: In this presentation I will shortly tell about Maemo ,the open source development platform for Internet Tablets. I will explain some of the problems (not fully opensource etc) while still explaining how great it is(canola2). Then I will switch to telling about mamona, the goals is strives (full open source stack) and it's roots (OE /bitbake). And finally I will show why it rules(e17 on a n810)!
event.description: Mamona itself is an embedded Linux distribution for ARM EABI. Mamona's main goal Project is to offer a completely open source alternative/experimental SDK package and flash image generation process for the Maemo Platform using only free and open source components.

event.title: Project Indiana: towards a free OpenSolaris LiveCD
event.abstract: The talk will give an overview of the IPS packaging system, the live CD and the strategy to simplify the operating system structures and the update cycles for patches.
event.description:
Project Indiana is working towards creating a binary distribution of an operating system built out of the OpenSolaris source code. The distribution is a point of integration for several current projects on OpenSolaris.org, including those to make the installation experience easier, to modernize the look and feel of OpenSolaris on the desktop, and to introduce a network-based package management system into Solaris.

The resulting distribution is a live-CD install image, and is fully permissible to be redistributed by anyone. It will also have the capability for developers to create their own, customized distribution based on Project Indiana. The first official release is due Spring 2008.

event.title: BSDA exam session 3
event.abstract: BSDA exam session #3

event.title: BSDA exam session 4
event.abstract: BSDA exam session #4

event.title: BSDA exam session 5
event.abstract: BSDA exam session #5

event.title: CakePHP
event.abstract: This session will introduce the latest version of the CakePHP framework.
event.description:
CakePHP is a rapid development framework for PHP, which derives principles from Ruby on Rails, and has since become a popular choice for building web applications.

We will start by looking at some of these principles behind CakePHP and continue by looking deeply into a CakePHP application. We will see how CakePHP reduces the amount of maintainable lines of code, while providing a robust and extensible architecture to handle the features needed for a web application.

With this knowledge, we can look at some of the more advanced features of CakePHP that make developers lives easier with simple approaches to common web application problems. Some of the features to be reviewed include the Bake command line code generation tool, application scaffolding, association data mapping, API services.

The talk will also share some of the history, heritage, and goals of the project.

Attend this talk to see why over 6500 developers have joined the CakePHP google group.

event.title: CentOS Debate
event.abstract: Workshop and discussions on and around CentOS. Open to everyone !

event.title: Hosting custom applications on CentOS 5
event.abstract: What is the best process to follow in order to host your own application on CentOS 5.
event.description: The talk aims to demonstrate what we feel is the best process someone might use in order to host their own application on CentOS-5, starting from adding the required packages to the distribution, customising the installer, deliverying the ISOs and install media as well as running custom repositories in order to push updates for users who would install this custom application + CentOS-5 combo.

event.title: Introduction to CentOS
event.abstract: The reasons why you need an enterprise Linux distro

event.title: An overview of SELinux in CentOS 5
event.abstract: drwxr-x--x is still the normal means of security under linux, giving access rights to data to users, groups and anyone else. This method isn't very flexible, so access rights are either given for larger groups of people or the administrator is tearing out his hair because he is lost in a maze of user, file and directory structures, which make working more than complex, but don't make the system more secure. Enter SELinux, a security infrastructure which is integrated into the kernel and promises to make securing your system more flexible.
event.description: SELinux is a security framework which is included in the kernel of the Linux operating system. Under SELinux files don't only have the normal access rights or ACLs, but also have a context. You as a user or a program have to be able to use that context to get access - even if normal access rights would allow you to change the file. This talk gives a short overview of SELinux and talks about the tools in CentOS 5 (and Fedora) which enable you to change the behaviour of SELinux.

event.title: CentOS 5 and Virtualization
event.abstract: An overview of the different virtualization possibilities using CentOS and the tools for managing them.
event.description:
Virtualization is useful in many situations, for instance to increase server utilization, to run legacy applications, and for application testing.

CentOS includes support for both paravirtualization (Xen) and hardware-assisted full-virtualization (Xen, KVM), with a generic virtualization library (libvirt) on top of them to make life easier for developers and system administrators.

This talk will introduce these technologies and, discusses their use uses. Additionally, provisioning of virtual machines with Cobbler will be touched upon.

event.title: CMake
event.abstract: This talk is about the CMake build system.
event.description:
CMake is a cross platform build system supporting Windows, Linux, UNIX, and Mac OSX platforms. Unlike other build system, CMake generates projects using the native build tools like KDevelop, Visual Studio, makefiles, and Xcode.

This allows developers to use the tools they are most productive with. In addition to building software, CMake provides a testing system called CTest, and a packaging system called CPack.

This talk will cover how to build, package and test software with the CMake family of tools.

event.title: Conary Packaging: Simply Powerful
event.abstract: Conary has a powerful set of tools for package building that make packaging easy -- not just compiling, but maintaining, updating, and testing.
event.description:
Michael will present http://wiki.rpath.com/wiki/Conary Conary] packaging, first demonstrating how simple the process is, then providing technical details of features that make packaging a simple, easy, repeatable process.

He will show how Conary handles common cases automatically, while making it easy to override its defaults for unusual cases.

Michael will also demonstrate how Conary improves packaging quality, by making packaging consistent and by providing tools to analyze packages and collections of packages.

Last but not least, he will explain how Conary's dependency management is different from legacy package management, encoding more thorough dependency information without requiring cascading piles of irrelevant packages.

event.title: The BSD (G)UI
event.abstract:
Linux usually comes packed with a nice and styled up graphical desktop environment to serve as an easy to use interface for users. As such it is ready to serve users who have only little understanding of computers.

But what does BSD offer? Does it come packed and ready to run for grandma? What user interfaces does BSD include natively and what does user interaction really mean in the BSD domain, having a much longer history than Linux?
event.description:
The purpose of user interaction is closely related to the actual purpose of the system in use. Is it a server with high availability requirements or a laptop for playing games with? With a longer tradition in the UNIX realm, BSD is highly optimized for good old shell use, which in some ways has not been surpassed in efficiency by anything else. The shell is definitely THE interface for a BSD operating system.

However, with growing maturity of desktop environments, BSDs can also be tailored to many needs requiring graphical interaction. In this respect, most BSD systems have integrated environments such as KDE, GNOME and XFCE into their packaging system.

As such, BSDs are usually much more flexible as to which desktop environment can be used. Except for desktop oriented BSD systems such as DesktopBSD, there is usually no precedence over which desktop environment is used. The choice is merrely up to the user ... or the super user.

Although desktop environments are available in a large number for the BSDs, general system interaction is still done through the shell. The desktop environments provide a nice graphical UI, but have not come close to the efficiency, completeness and popularity of shells. A very important factor for this fact is that common desktop environments usually don't provide the neccessary tools for system configuration tasks. On Linux they usually do - either natively or provided through the distributor.

The reason why shells are still so commonly used on BSD systems is probably because the average BSD user is rather experienced with Unix in general and thus used to a shell environment which is the only complete interface to a Unix. Coupled with the popularity of desktop environments, the result is usually that some desktop environment is used, with the most common application being a shell interfaces like Konsole, xterm or whatever.

This shows that the focus is still on the operating system to which the principle interface is the shell.

BSD already provides a very liberal infrastructure in terms of user interfaces. Most desktop environments are well supported and none is mandatory. Provided with such a basis, it may be worthwhile to explore further possibilities of user interaction and technology layers. At some point it will be necessary to grow beyond the operating system and closer to the user - the human being - in order for computer systems to become more natural.

In this talk we will explore the different interfaces to a common BSD operating system and what purpose they serve. Of course the shell is a big thing on such a system, however, desktop environments are already commonly in use even within the BSD family. Further concepts for user interaction will be discussed. A major focus of the talk will be the infrastructure that makes it possible on BSD systems to run various user interfaces and how such a liberal environment can be utilized for clean technology research to reach beyond current limitations and growing towards the user.

event.title: Crossdesktop closing talk
event.abstract: Final words, discussions, ...

event.title: CMake: News and Secrets
event.abstract: CMake is a powerful cross platform buildsystem. In 2006 the KDE project switched its buildsystem to CMake and today KDE 4.0.0 is shipping and building on Linux, FreeBSD, Solaris, Mac OSX and Windows.
event.description: The talk will present some of the less well known features of CMake, like packaging using CPack and unit testing using CTest, and it will also introduce some of the exciting new features CMake 2.6.0 will bring, e.g cross compiling, new project generators, deb and rpm support, language improvements and more.

event.title: Deb Packaging Introduction
event.abstract: A tutorial to get you started making .deb packages.
event.description: Learn how to make .deb packages. This interactive tutorial will take you through packaging an application.

event.title: Free Software in Education
event.abstract: Many believes that free software can't be used in education, and still some parents mandates schools to use MS Office. Knut Yrvin will show that software in education are everything else than office productivity.
event.description: It's about sharing, learning and creating. He will present free software usable for learning focusing on Stopmotion and Gcompris in primary schools to using Qtopia on mobile phones at universities.

event.title: Farsight 2: Video conferencing made easy
event.abstract: Farsight 2 is a next-generation GStreamer based videoconferencing framework, used in the Telepathy framework, Nokia Internet tablets, etc. It supports advanced features multi-party conferencing, lip-sync, etc.
event.description: Olivier will present a bit of the history of farsight, what it does, and show a nice cool demo and a three slide VoIP program.

event.title: GEGL
event.abstract: GEGL - the image processing library; not the goat. Cool things done since last year, experiences and consequences of GIMP integration, and interesting things the developers will be happy when are removed from the to-do list.

event.title: KDE 4
event.abstract: The KDE 4 talk will be about the current status of KDE 4.0, outline some of its core technologies and talk about what is upcoming in the next versions.

event.title: klik on KDE and Gnome - chances and challenges
event.abstract: klik2 will be the first real implementation of the ''"1 application == 1 file"'' concept of applying the idea of virtualization not only to the OS/machine, but also on the level of single (or multiple) applications. klik1 was our proof-of-concept that worked out really well in Bash. Today's klik2 is implemented in Python. (There are more details about the differences in this FOSDEM speaker interview).
event.description:
klik will be very beneficial in various use cases that span a big range of user types:

  • Grandpa Angus wants to easily run the latest firefox browser without messing with his system's installation by just clicking on the firefox3.cmg bundle that his grand-daughter sent her by email.
  • Developer Benjamin wanting to deploy his nightly builds of coolapp to his team of non-technical contributors so that they can polish documentation, translations, artwork with the real thing running in front of their eyes.
  • Company CopyCatCom wanting to deliver their first Linux port of a previously Windows-only application on a CD, where it can be started from without actual "installation" as is known.
  • Live CD developer Dave wants to offer an easy way to his users so that they can add more software to the system while it is running -- software that he has no time to package himself.
Now that we have the basic concepts working, it is time to also seek the support of developers from the Gnome and the KDE camps to help us solve some of the specific problems we are facing on each of the platforms. '''''Some examples:''' KDE (3 and 4) in general is highly integrated, and applications are closely linked to many features built deeply of the KDE library system. klik's application virtualization does seem to run contrary to this pattern, since it "isolates" the application, by encapsulating it into a single file. klik-ified KDE3 applications which include their own documentation sometimes aren't able to show them via the local system's KDE Help Center. KDE's Sycoca (System Configuration Cache) sometimes is re-building too slowly for a klik-ed application; sometimes it seems to not achieve at all what is needed. What is the best way to update KDE and Gnome menus with entries about newly klik-ed applications? What is the best way to update Gnome's configuration system when a klik-ed app is running?''

event.title: Integrating the Web into GTK+ applications with WebKit
event.abstract: WebKit/GTK+ is a brand new port of the WebKit content engine aiming for standards compliance, high performance and seamless integration with the GTK+ stack. I'll be demonstrating some of the latest features as well as taking a look at how various GNOME applications like IM clients, mailers and feed readers have adopted the WebView API.

event.title: Welcome to the Crossdesktop room
event.abstract: Opening of the Crossdesktop developer room.

event.title: How accessible is Debian?
event.abstract: This talk will introduce the audience to accessibility, report successes and failures, address the future remaining challenges, and also tell about the small but so useful little thingies that every debian developer can do to make Debian yet more accessible.
event.description: Accessibility (a11y) has recently brought more and more attention in the OSS community, notably through the A11Y OpenGroup. Debian is actually one of the leaders among distributions in terms of accessibility: braille devices are notably supported right from the official debian-installer to the Gnome desktop, for instance. On the other hand, braille devices are expensive, so that quite a few people will resort to speech synthesis, and these, though working on an installed system, are not officially supported right from the installer.

event.title: The Belgian electronic ID card in Debian
event.abstract: A few years ago, the Belgian government decided to replace its ID card with an electronic version, and they made the decision to make the software to read data from this ID card free (as in speech). Wouter has packaged this software for Debian, and will give an introduction on its benefits, downsides, and the practical use of the eID in Debian.
event.description: This talk is being held in response to a similar talk that was held last year, in the CentOS Developers' room.

event.title: Reordering the Debian boot sequence for correctness and speed
event.abstract: There are subtle bugs in the debian boot and shutdown sequence. They are hard to find, as they normally only affect rare combination of packages, and harder to fix, as they normally require the combined work of several maintainers and changes in several packages.
event.description:
One way to find these bugs is to document the dependencies of all init.d scripts, and use this information to check that the ordering is correct. When such information is available, it is also possible to reorder the boot and shutdown sequence to make sure all dependencies are fulfilled.

It is also possible to run scripts in parallel, to speed up the boot, when the order they need to run in is known.

This talk is about how all of this can be done with Debian.

event.title: The long road to Debian Edu in main
event.abstract: This talk will briefly explain what Debian Edu is, how we develop our distribution, how we differ from Debian, how we work on bridging the gaps that still exist and what our plans for the future are.
event.description:
In July 2007 the Debian Edu project released its third release, codename "Skolelinux 3.0 Terra". Debian Edu is probably the most widely known and most widely used Custom Debian Distribution - at least if you follow the official criteria for a CDD, which we aim to finally fulfill 100% for Lenny: all packages are taken unmodified from Debian main.

This talk will explain the development process of Debian Edu and the various differences to a default Debian install. An overview of the planned features for Lenny will be given as well as a list of current showstoppers will be presented.

Using wiki.debian.org to write a fine manual will be explained briefly too: our documentation is written in a wiki, then exported as docbook and translated using .po files, then transfered back into docbook, to generate html and PDFs versions, which are made available in the debian-edu-doc package, which is installed on a webserver again.

event.title: Lenny: the past and the future
event.abstract:
In this talk at least the following questions should get a decent answer:

  • What happened since Etch and what will hopefully happen before Lenny?
  • What is the Release schedule?
  • What are the Release Goals?
  • What does still need to happen?
  • How can I help?

event.title: Running Debian on Inexpensive Network Storage Devices
event.abstract: Network Storage Devices (NAS) are gaining popularity and are available quite inexpensively. For most customers, they are basically just a hard drive that you connect to the network for file storage. In reality, these devices are complete, even if fairly low-end, computers - and Debian can be installed on some of them.
event.description: This talk will show how combining a NAS with Debian gives you a low-power and quiet server for home use. In particular, this talk will cover new devices that are based on Marvell's Orion platform, such as the KuroBox Pro and in particular the QNAP TS-201.

event.title: Creating a nice view into the Debian archives
event.abstract: This talks presents an overview over the code running behind packages.debian.org (and packages.ubuntu.com), its history, its design, its problems, and its future.
event.description: Finally it will include a short introduction on how to hack on the code to improve it.

event.title: etch-n-half: Supporting new hardware within stable
event.abstract: Debian Etch has been released a bit more than a year ago. Since then new hardware has appeared. We are about to release the first real "servicepack" to etch which adds support for e.g. newer graphic cards. This update will also contain other important improvements to stable.

event.title: Update on Virtualization in Debian
event.abstract: As a follow up of the talk at last year's debconf, Henning Sprang will give an overview of the things happened in Debian in the meantime in the area of virtualization.
event.description: Which tools and technologies are available in Debian, who are the new kids on the block which we can look forward to have available in the next stable release of Debian.

event.title: What's new in Drupal 6
event.abstract: What's new in Drupal 6

event.title: Combining Amazon Web Services with Drupal
event.abstract: An introduction to Amazon Web Services (S3, EC2, SQS) and their integration in Drupal, illustrated with a showcase.
event.description:
Very recently, a module to integrate Drupal with Amazon Web Services was released. Even though it is still in early development, it can be very useful to find out what can be done with it by demonstrating examples of Drupal websites which integrate AWS.

Taking wikifonia.org, a community website for sheet music, as an example, we'll see how S3, SQS and EC2 can be used with Drupal. I will focus on the software architecture, data flow and some challenges which we faced.

event.title: Introducing the Apache Solr Module
event.abstract: Robert Douglass introduces the ApacheSolr module - next generation search for Drupal sites.
event.description:
The ApacheSolr module allows Drupal sites to integrate with Lucene/Solr for a comprehensive search solution that exceeds Drupal's core search in performance and features. From faceted searching to searching across multiple sites, ApacheSolr opens up a world of new possibilities.

Join Robert as he explains the fundamental concepts behind this technology and demonstrates its features.

event.title: Asset Management in Drupal using the Asset Module
event.abstract: This talk will illustrate the asset management problem in content management systems and how the Asset module tries to solve it.
event.description:
The Asset module tries to tackle asset management in a highly integrated manner. It provides integration with cck, views, panels and imagecache.

There is also a TinyMCE plug-in for inserting and managing assets or an "Add asset" link below textareas if TinyMCE is not enabled. Image galleries are created using a special panels field. Any type of file can be added, many of which have specific plug-ins or players to display them: mp3, flv, swf, youtube, ...

event.title: Challenges for the CMS of Tomorrow and its Developers
event.abstract: Social Networking Systems in the Professional Arena and Digital Business Ecosystems:The Challenges for the CMS of Tomorrow and its Developers.
event.description:
One cannot fail to spot the rising success of social networking systems, such as Facebook and Myspace. Millions of users worldwide use these applications to identify themselves on the web, connect and interact with others around them. Therefore it is understandable that businesses, organizations and governments alike are increasingly interested in similar applications in order to support their operations. However, quite a number of challenges remain as the requirements of these organizations are quite different from youngsters interacting with each other.

In this talk we identify what our own and other research has shown to be a number of major issues remaining which remain to be addressed before social networking systems can come closer to live up to their true potential in this area.

Why should people within or between companies connect, interact and share knowledge and ideas after all ? Are current systems ready to handle sensitive corporate information ? These are just two of many questions.

event.title: Drupal and MySQL High Availability
event.abstract: If you are lucky, one day your Drupal installment will need more than one database to handle the load your users generate. Or your installment will become so critical you can't afford your database to be down.
event.description:
Lots of people use MySQL as the backend for their Drupal setup. This session will introduce you to the different methods of making MySQL High Available as well as the pitfalls in those methods. Amongst the alternatives we'll discuss MySQL Cluster, and how to integrate it with your environment so that not only the data stays available but also your MySQL Daemon.

As of 5.1 MySQL got a new feature called disk based cluster, however not all tables can benefit from it. We'll have a closer look where it can help Drupal.

event.title: Implementing Drupal for the Public Sector
event.abstract: Lessons Learned from Implementing Drupal in the Dutch Municipality of Vughten, followed by a Techal Case Study.
event.description:
Frank will talk about politics and motivation while Michel will discuss some technical issues, illustrated by 3 custom modules .

The municipality of Vught in the Netherlands will launch a new website based on Drupal in February. National government has implemented several programs to realize more online information, services and participation, both on a national as well as the local level. Traditional ICT structures struggle with these new demands.

This presentation will discuss the political, organisational and technical context and demands that have lead us to choose Drupal to build our closely integrated internet and intranet websites with. We will present the client's view of the development process and discuss our plans for further development.

event.title: Drupal Theming
event.abstract: Getting started with Theming + advanced theming concepts and tricks.
event.description:
• Introduction in Drupal theming:
* What can it do for you? * How and when do you use it?
  • Introducing the differences between Drupal 5 theming and 6.
  • Hands-on example of a theme override.

event.title: Usability and Drupal
event.abstract: Some Results of the Drupal Usability Group and further Plans
event.description:
At the Drupalcon Barcelona it started: We had a BoF on the Usability of Drupal. A subset of the people involved kept up IRC Meetings ever since. We developed Ideas and marked areas to start with to improve Drupals usability. It feels like a giant task, because a lot and a lot has to be done.

At DrupalCon Barcelona, the Usability Group saw the light of day. A subset of those involved in Barcelona continued the Usability efforts and Thomas will present where we are at this point, illustrated with mockups, modules and proofs of concept.

event.title: Web Service Development for Managers
event.abstract: WSDM is a course in development, it is running its second test year in a Master after Master class and will be integrated in the new Master of Management for next year. The goal of the course is to learn students to use the internet and open source as part of there business plan when creating a service.
event.description: The student need to develop a project. In the first phase basic php is learned, continued with a exercise on creating a Drupal module. During that phase the student has to define a "service on the web" project (not to confuse with web services). The second phase is the focus of the course. With the project the course becomes more individual and several options to integrate are possible. The development shift from programming to problem solving. The course is managed by putting up some clear criteria at front, related to communication, functionality and reusability.

event.title: Welcome to the Drupal devroom
event.abstract: Welcome to the Drupal devroom at FOSDEM 2008.

event.title: Emdebian Update: Rootfs, GPE and tdebs
event.abstract: This talk covers the current status of the Embedded Debian project, preparation of a cross built Debian root filesystem for ARM with support for customisation, improved translation support in Emdebian and the next steps to making Debian available to embedded devices.
event.description: Also includes the status of GPE packages in Debian and Emdebian and a description of the Emdebian implementation of Tdebs - translation packages with secondary repository and cache support.

event.title: GNUStep on embedded devices
event.abstract: With the introduction of the iPhone that bases parts of its GUI on Apples Objc-C and OpenSTEP implementation, it appears that the time has come to consider to use the open source variant GUNstep in other embedded solutions. The mySTEP project already addresses this goal by optimizing and adapting GNUstep to the needs of embedded processors especially in handheld devices. Using all these tools, it allows to develop cross-platform software for Mac, Linux, Windows - and Linux handhelds.
event.description:
Topics to be addresses in the talk:

  • Why should one consider Objective-C and GNUstep for embedded devices?
  • What frameworks does mySTEP provide? How do they compare to Cocoa?
  • Comparison of mySTEP with the iPhone SDK (if we know anything public by FOSDEM).
  • Special considerations for using GNUstep on embedded devices.
  • Performance evaluation. Life demo on OpenMoko Neo 1973. Future development.

event.title: Controlling embedded devices with the Maemo internet tablet
event.abstract: Linux based internet tablets provide inexpensive and powerful computers for embedded applications. However they have limited means to control external devices.
event.description:
In this presentation Kate will show methods to enhance tablet I/O capabilities and methods to interface with external microcontroller based embedded controllers.

She will be taking care of both software and hardware aspects in both tablet and embedded controller side and also demonstrating some open source applications on how we can control external harware with interfacing microcontrollers and an internet tablet.

event.title: OpenWrt
event.abstract: OpenWrt is described as a Linux distribution for embedded devices.
event.description:
Instead of trying to create a single, static firmware, OpenWrt provides a fully writable filesystem with package management. This frees you from the application selection and configuration provided by the vendor and allows you to customize the device through the use of packages to suit any application.

For developers, OpenWrt is the framework to build an application without having to build a complete firmware around it; for users this means the ability for full customization, to use the device in ways never envisioned.

event.title: pjsip: lightweight portable SIP stack
event.abstract: (TBD)

event.title: Free software in Telecom focusing on Qtopia
event.abstract: Community Manager Knut Yrvin at Trolltech will present mobile phone programming with Qtopia on Greenphone.
event.description: He will focus on game programming and Telenors Program for Advanced Telecom Services. When developing free software for phones, you don't pay for using GSM production network for non-commercial purposes. Trolltech ASA has a research and innovation program with Telenor. Telenor is an international wireless carrier with 135 million customers world wide.

event.title: Design a Linux robot companion with 8 bits microcontrollers
event.abstract: Ever got tempted to program those small 8 bits microcontrollers but were afraid at the first glance of a schematic?
event.description:
David will be talking about his experience in designing and programming 8 bits embedded platforms with Open Source tools. He will attempt to demystify the electronic side of embedded projects by adopting a software developer approach. The Tux Droid Open Source robot will be used as an example.

A broad look at embedded design will be presented, from hardware design and realization to embedded programming and computer interfaces.

A more detailed walk-through will cover how to choose a microcontroller, peripherals, interfaces with various hardware blocks, major communication bus, development toolchain, JTAG or other in-circuit debugging techniques and interfacing your MCU with a computer.

David will finish with an overview of some end-user applications developed for the robot. These are good examples of how you could expand the power of small microcontrollers with the technology available from your computer.

event.title: Tomoyo Linux for secure embedded (Linux)
event.abstract: TOMOYO Linux is a MAC (Mandatory Access Control) implementation for Linux.
event.description:
It was developed by NTT DATA CORPORATION, Japan and is available under the GPL license. TOMOYO Linux consists of patch files to vanilla kernel and userland tools.

Patch files are provided for both 2.4 and 2.6. For the user's convenience, various binary packages are also available.

event.title: UPnP: dead simple, or simply deadly ?
event.abstract: One of the protocols that is in wide use on embedded devices (routers, mediaplayers, etcetera) is Universal Plug and Play (UPnP). The protocol was designed by Microsoft in the late 1990s to adapt the plug and play concept as used for USB on desktop machines to the world of networked devices. Now, nearly ten years later there are a lot of devices that use UPnP.
event.description:
The UPnP protocol enables programs to do a lot of things automatically, for which normally a system administrator is needed, such as opening ports in firewalls in the case of routers. While it is convenient for normal users it enables a whole range of interesting attacks. The complete lack of authentication, combined with grave programming errors leads to situations where an attacker can gain complete control over devices, including reconfiguring firewalls and remote code execution. Many exploits were discussed and revealed at the SANE 2006 conference in Delft, The Netherlands, but new exploits keep popping up.

One of the latest exploits takes UPnP hacking to the web, using a Flash program and cross site scripting.

In this talk I will show why UPnP was developed, where the errors in common implementations are (and the reason why: the ODM development model), why you should care and what you can do to make sure you are not an attractive target. Exploit code will be shown.

event.title: The Endgame
event.abstract: Description will come soon...

event.title: Something new about LVM2
event.abstract: Something new about LVM2
event.description: LVM is a logical volume manager for the Linux kernel. It was originally written in 1998 by Heinz Mauelshagen, who based its design on that of the LVM in HP-UX.

event.title: Smolt and Web Application Privacy
event.abstract: This presentation will go over some of what Smolt can do for you and your Linux distribution.
event.description: It will also cover some of the privacy issues related to Smolt, how they are solved using standard security features, and how they can be used in other web applications.

event.title: Migrating from Linux to FreeBSD
event.abstract: n/a

event.title: pbi - the new paket management system
event.abstract: n/a

event.title: Cool stuff
event.abstract: Lots of examples of cool work in progress.
event.description: Real hackers show their work, how they do their work and where it takes Free Java next. Examples are gstreamer integration, graphics through the framebuffer, jnode a full os in java, NetBeans for HotSpot hacking and Jalimo bringing Free Java to maemo and openmoko devices.

event.title: Distro Rumble
event.abstract: So which GNU/Linux distribution integrates java packages best? Find out during this distro shootout!
event.description: How do the various GNU/Linux distributions integrate java based libraries and applications into their packaging systems. How can we improve cross-distro packaging guidelines (filesystem layout, packaging inter-dependencies, browser integration, developer guidelines, etc.) used across GNU/Linux distributions for java libraries and programs?

event.title: The Free Java Factory
event.abstract: OpenJDK and IcedTea, how are they made and how do you test them?
event.description: In the factory there will be discussions about functional testing and quality, an overview of the work of the client team and an overview of the transformation process that turns openjdk/hotspot into icedtea with some spicy applet, liveconnect and webstart support.

event.title: Java: Freedom, Compatibility and Community
event.abstract: How to combine the holy trinity of Free Java? Freedom, Compatibility and Community.
event.description: Java is Free! Now how do we keep it that way? How do we measure compatibity? What about this mysterious and non-free JCK? What is the future of the JCP process? Where does the community come in and how can you help?

event.title: JIT Session: Discussion Topics Dynamically Loaded
event.abstract: This block is reserved for elaborating on Free Java issues which have not yet had enough coverage. Want to hear about -- or talk about -- something the Free Java world and don't see a topic on the agenda? This time is reserved for late binding discussion.

event.title: JIT Session: Free Java plans for 2008
event.abstract: Setting the agenda for Free Java 2008: community objectives for the next year, optimized on the fly

event.title: Hudson
event.abstract: Kohsuke Kawaguchi talks about Hudson, a continuous integration system that he's been developing for the last few years. It is a web application that continuously builds your project and keeps track of what's happening.
event.description:
A part of the talk will be about the general introduction of it and what it can do. A demo will be shown, and a highlight of most interesting technologies behind Hudson.

These include the plugin system, the remoting infrastructure, the way distributed builds are handled, how installation is simplified, and the avoidance of cryptic URLs in a very REST-full web application.

event.title: Workflow In Java
event.abstract: JBoss jBPM is an open source platform that supports workflow, business process management, and service orchestration.
event.description:
Though BPEL has a big brand name associated to BPM, people start to realize that it is not a silver bullet. Recently two process component models have taken a different point of view. Multiple process languages are taken as the goal and process component models are frameworks on which multiple languages can be build.

We'll look at some examples of the Process Virtual Machine and explain how this technology can be used as the basis for workflow, BPM and orchestration. Attending this talk will give a good overview of the complete JBoss jBPM project.

event.title: Application virtualization with next-generation Klik
event.abstract: The talk will start with a short live demonstration of klik2 and then proceed into the technical aspects of creating a format and implementation for providing cross-distro application images.
event.description:
Klik is all about virtualization on the application level.

We are all familiar with virtualization at the operating system or PC hardware level. klik applies the same idea to a different level: namely the level of individual applications.

Klik creates applications that are encapsulated into a single file. This file in fact is a compressed file system image similar to the ISO image format that we know from burning data CDs. Hence, klik is the implementation of the ''"1 application == 1 file"'' principle.

While this might sound complicated, the idea is really very easy: Take an application and put it together with everything (libraries, icons, data files, configuration files, man pages, manuals and other resources) it needs for successful execution into an ISO image, from which you can run it. You can then easily move the file, take it with you on a USB stick, send it to a friend.

Your application will run on any major distribution, without the need for an installation as we know it. That's the basic idea, but implementation isn't trivial, as will be discussed in the talk. After a brief live demonstration, Pfeiffle and Peter will dive into the technical details of the upcoming implementation code-named "klik2".

event.title: LPI exam session 3
event.abstract: LPI exam session #3

event.title: LPI exam session 4
event.abstract: LPI exam session #4

event.title: LPI exam session 5
event.abstract: LPI exam session #5

event.title: Build systems with autotools and libtool
event.abstract: n/a

event.title: Electronic Ombuds: Firefighting in Online Communities
event.abstract: This session teaches community managers and community members effective processes for helping keep heated discussions on track, recovering from flamewars and managing the really tough issues in a transparent and just fashion. We'll cover the basics of electronic ombuds, triage a flamefest from a popular mailing list and teach essential survival tactics for those who would venture into the flames.
event.description:
It's 4am. An innocuous-looking thread on your community mailing list has grown into a 500 message flamefest. The good, the bad and the vulgar are mixed together - often even in the same message. There are pleas for sanity, demands for moderation, off-topic rants and paranoid accusations.

In short, it is just another day on the net. It could be your community or it could be mine - it doesn't really matter. What matters is helping the community recover gracefully and ensuring that the future holds discussion that are equally vibrant but less traumatic for all involved.

This session teaches community managers and community members effective processes for helping keep discussions on track, recovering from flamewars and managing the really tough issues in a transparent and just fashion.

In 45 minutes, we'll cover the basics of electronic ombuds, triage a flamefest from a popular mailing list and teach some essential survival tactics for those who would venture into the flames.

event.title: EU Community Survey
event.abstract: Seth Bindernagel, Pascal Chevrel, Stas Malolepszy will present results from two surveys conducted with the Mozilla European community.
event.description: Stas and Pascal created an online survey tool and Seth and Stas constructed two surveys that were sent out for response. The surveys relate to the overall health of the Mozilla community and Mozilla community's efforts at "customer support". Stas and Seth then analyzed all data and will present findings.

event.title: Extensions Workshop
event.abstract: A workshop aimed at extension developers who wish to update their extensions for the upcoming Firefox 3 release. It is not exclusive to Firefox extensions, authors of extensions for other Mozilla-based software are welcome.
event.description: See Fosdem:2008:Workshop for more information.

event.title: Miro
event.abstract: The online video space risks being ruled by proprietary software (like Flash), DRM, and gatekeepers (Google/Youtube). Miro is our best strategy against that, and our best strategy for an online video world where users are in charge. I'll talk about what Miro does, what's cool about it, and how you can help.
event.description:
Miro is like a TV on your computer. And Miro is a strategy for democratizing media and cracking open the online video space.

Miro subscribes to RSS feeds, downloads videos, seamlessly integrates Bittorrent, and it plays practically every video format. Users can browse a "Channel Guide" of free video RSS feeds in a built-in web browser. Miro is available for Linux, Mac, and Windows, and it was downloaded over 2 million times last year.

It's made by Participatory Culture Foundation, a mission-based nonprofit (NGO) who's goal is to open up media.

event.title: Mozilla Mobile
event.abstract: Mozilla's Mobile effort has been renewed. Full time staff has been added and work to create a roadmap and technology demonstrations are underway. Come learn about recent progress, and explore how you can get involved in creating a great mobile browser that leverages all the benefits of the Mozilla and Firefox codebase.

event.title: Community Project Organisation and Seamonkey 2
event.abstract: The talk will provide an overview of volunteer-driven community project organisation and specifically SeaMonkey 2 development.
event.description: Driving and organizing a volunteer project is challenging every day. Mozilla community projects have their own specific set of infrastructure that help ease part of those, but also their own difficulties. This talk will shed a light on those as well as other issues concerning SeaMonkey development (like web discrimination), with a short glimpse on what SeaMonkey 2 will bring to the world of the legendary Internet suite.

event.title: OOoCalc Formula Compiler and Expression Interpreter Workshop
event.abstract: The workshop will give an overview and some in-depth knowledge of how the spreadsheet formula parser/compiler and interpreter work, the concept behind it, the files and classes they use and how those interact with each other.
event.description: Focus will be on the changes that they are currently undergoing, why they are needed, what is missing and how developers could help to implement new spreadsheet functions or rework already existing functions. This on the background of the work of the OASIS OpenDocument Format Formula (ODFF aka OpenFormula) subcommittee (members being implementors of OOoCalc, Gnumeric, KSpread and others) that drafted a specification of functions and operators used in spreadsheet formulas.

event.title: OpenOffice.org extensions development in Java with NetBeans in practise
event.abstract: This workshop will explain how developers can use the OpenOffice.org API plugin for NetBeans for developing with and for OpenOffice.org in Java.
event.description:
The popularity of the standardized (OASIS and ISO/IEC 26300) Open Document Format for Office Applications (OpenDocument) is growing. This also drives the popularity of OpenOffice.org office in government agencies and enterprises. Corporate users often demand the integration of office productivity into existing workflows and applications. They also often require additional functionality or special customizations of the existing features.

OpenOffice.org offers a language independent application programming interface (API) which allows to program OpenOffice.org in Java. It allows to use OpenOffice.org as service provider in other applications, extend it with new functionality or simply customize and control OpenOffice.org.

Typical use cases are document creation, conversion or printing from remote client applications (typical server scenarios). Embedding office functionality into own Java applications to make use of the rich feature set. For example using the editor of the word processor application with all its features in your own application. Or intercept and replace existing commands with own implementations. For example replace the standard save/load commands to save/load directly into/from a document management system (DMS). Alternatively it is possible to insert additional save/load menu entries to support the DMS additionally. Do you have thought about embedding your own Java component into an OpenOffice.org writer document? Embed Java components and activate them outplace in an external window. The use cases can be extended easily and it is obvious that both the OpenOffice.org and the Java world can benefit from each other.

The OpenOffice.org API plugin for NetBeans helps to use this API most effectively from NetBeans. The workshop will give an overview of the provided features of the plugin and will explain step by step how to - use wizards to create complete extensions for OpenOffice.org - deploy extensions directly from NetBeans into a running office program - debug the running extensions in NetBeans

And in more detail the audience will learn how to develop an own Smart Tag extensions for the OpenOffice.org Writer application. Smart Tags are known from a well known other office application and are new in OpenOffice.org since version 2.3. Smart Tags open the door for creativity and a lot of small, nice and probably useful new features (implemented as extensions) for the Writer application.

A second example will explain step by step how to implement an options dialog pane for an own extension. More comprehensive extensions often allow the configuration of options and a well integrated options pane in the default office options dialog make extensions looking more professional and helps to improve the overall user experience of the office. Users can find all configuration in one place under Tools - Options.

The workshop examples are explained in detail and step by step. The provided workshop material provides links to further background documentation.

event.title: Hacking OpenOffice.org for beginners
event.abstract: Hack OpenOffice.org on Mac OS X or Linux, for beginners.
event.description:
Prerequisites: people willing to write C++ code, and/or fix bug ..or whatever around coding.

1. Checking out the sources 1.1 Presenting the Master workspaces and the branches

  • OOH680
  • SRC680 -> DEV300
1.2 Presenting what a Child workspace is
  • bases
  • cwstools
  • resync
1.3 Presenting what a Milestone is
  • based on reference milestone
  • completed with cws
  • rules
1.3 Presenting the tools: cvs (add some words about svn and git if possible)
  • the essential: cvs, bonsai IZ and LXR
2 Steps for the build 2.1 Rules for a clean build
  • use clean sources
  • build childworkspace with the exact milestone it is based on
2.1 Configure : possibilities, examples for Mac OS X, add a locale (where is it located in the code)
  • with X / without X / mozilla , configure --help .. etc, wiki pages for a build
2.2 The build:
  • present the building system : what, when , how -> present build.lst and d.lst
    • the boostrap -> makefile
    • dmake and build
    • present the directories: where is what
  • Eric will explain a complete building dependencies diagram for 2.x , and make the parallel with buil.lst files.
2.4 The product
  • present all possible formats
  • how is everything packaged ?
3 Advanced build
  • work with child workspaces : rules
  • Present EIS and how use it
  • rebuild a module including symbols
  • ... and debug
  • create patches
4 Meet us

event.title: OOo/ODF Integration using the OO.org SDK
event.abstract: OO.o/ODF Integration into other productivity application's by using the OO.org SDK. The interest in OpenOffice.org and its file format, called Open Document Format (ODF), has been growing in the past few years. This has resulted in increased demand to integrate productivity applications into OpenOffice.org and support for ODF.
event.description: The presenter is going to share his experiences that he has acquired in migration and integration projects at customers of Sun Microsystems during the past 11 years. The presentation will show the necessary steps the developer has to make for achieving the required integration by using a project that the presenter has supported. After the presentation the attendee is able to provide the appropriate infrastructure to enable the user to use the functions of other productivity applications in Openoffice.org.

event.title: Creating OpenOffice.org Wizards
event.abstract: This workshop would be about the practical steps to create an OpenOffice.org wizard.
event.description:
Describe an (existing) PDF-converterthat roughly contains about 1000 lines of sourcecode and converts documents to PDF format.

In this workshop the following topics will be handled:

  • Design of graphical user interfaces based on OpenOffice.org API and (maybe) also other platforms like Java Swing.
  • Where do I get API related Information - work with the OpenOffice-SDK, interface and service descriptions. In this context I will also introduce the object inspector
as a helpful extension to inspect Uno -objects during runtime
  • Remote control of an Office application.
  • Practical use of services and interfaces.

event.title: X.org and BSD, changes ahead
event.abstract: This talk is going to adress some of the on-going changes in the X server architecture, and how they will (or won't) impact BSD systems.

event.title: openQRM, pluggable virtualization for modern data-centers
event.abstract: This presentation deals with the pluggable virtualization architecture of openQRM and describes how to conform and automate deployment, management, maintenance and migration of physical systems and virtual machines seamlessly. It provides an detailed overview about the openQRM virtualization plugins and their integration within the data-center management platform.
event.description:
To ease up the management and maintenance of modern data-centers the current evolution of virtualization technologies directs system administrators more and more to virtual server appliances. One of the goals is a server-Image based deployment including and automated resource management plus the possibility to easy migrate physical systems to virtual machines (P2V). Other targets are the option to move from one virtualization type to a different one (V2V) to avoid vendor-locks by bounding a complete data-center to a single virtualization technology and also the support for migrating virtual appliances back to physical systems (V2P).

To conform with current mainstream virtualization technologies, e.g. VMware, Xen, Qemu and Linux-VServer, openQRM provides a generic virtualization layer, the “partition-bridge”. Via a well-defined API the openQRM virtualization plugins are interfacing with this “partition-bridge” to unify the resource management by adding additional virtual resources from the type “partition”. As the result in openQRM virtual machines are managed in the same way as physical systems and the system administrator may decide at any time to run a specific server-image on real hardware, move it to a VMware partition, from there to a Xen partition and back to a real, physical existing server without any changes on the server-Image itself nor hassling with the different virtualization configuration files..

This presentation deals with the pluggable virtualization architecture of openQRM and describes how to conform and automate deployment, management, maintenance and migration of physical systems and virtual machines seamlessly. It provides an detailed overview about the openQRM virtualization plugins and their integration within the data-center management platform.

event.title: Desktop accessibility & UI Automation
event.abstract: Accessibility is a hot topic, as is interoperability, I'll talk about how we will bring the new UI Automation API to OpenSUSE, allowing Mono/Winforms apps to run un-modified on Linux, the differences in the APIs, and the various challenges here.

event.title: EnergyStar: Jump on the bandwagon!
event.abstract:
• What does EnergyStar actually stand for. What are the key facts regarding laptops. Don't we just have to blame the manufacturers?
  • What it makes interesting for both developers and users. Is openSUSE ready?
  • How to test your laptop for EnergyStar compliance (if time permits)

event.title: GNOME on openSUSE 11.0
event.abstract:
GNOME and openSUSE 11.0:

  • GNOME 2.22 Features and highlights
  • GNOME and SUSE: PackageKit, zypp, yast-gtk, pulseaudio, compiz/xgl
  • openSUSE/GNOME Community

event.title: KDE 4 on openSUSE 11
event.abstract:
KDE 4 on openSUSE 11:

  • KDE 4 on openSUSE 11.0: The best of both worlds
  • Scripting KDE 4 (Demonstration)
  • Challenges of the KDE one CD installation media

event.title: Kernel, udev, D-Bus, HAL, NetworkManager and Friends
event.abstract:
• What are those components, how are they glued together?
  • Debugging made easy: How to solve issues within the stack.
  • Use D-Bus for application development to profit from the whole stack.

event.title: System Imaging with KIWI
event.abstract: Explain how users can make their own linux with custom software on a concrete example

event.title: mod_zrkadlo, the openSUSE redirector
event.abstract: Scaling a download infrastructure with your success.
event.description:
When an organization offers files for download, and grows public, infrastructure might need to serve more requests than the single organization can technically handle. One option to scale is using paid services of a content delivery network (CDN). This is often not affordable, especially for Open Source projects. Another way is building up a mirror infrastructore. But choosing an appropriate mirror is often left to the user, and mirrors might be out of date, incomplete, or unreliable.

This talk shows how to build a poor man's CDN, using plain mirror servers and a redirecting Apache HTTP server. On the example of download.openSUSE.org, it shows how mirrored content can be transparently integrated into the web service, and how requests are redirected to geographically close mirrors using IP geolocation. The demonstrated infrastructure comprises means to scan mirrors and keeping track of present files in a MySQL database, active monitoring of mirrors, and mod_zrkadlo, a redirecting Apache module built upon the DBD framework.

Along the way, the talk discusses different approaches in geographical redirection of bulk data, load sharing with weighted randomization, high availibility and scaling issues, mirror stickiness, and client side robustness. Also discussed are problems that have been encountered in real life, solutions and open questions.

event.title: One Click Install
event.abstract: One Click Install: What it is, How to Leverage it, and Future Improvements.
event.description: A new feature known as "One Click Install" was introduced in openSUSE 10.3, this helped improve the user experience of locating and installing software. This talk will explain the reasons for the technology, how it works, and demonstrate some current and future uses within the openSUSE project. It will be shown how software vendors can utilise the technology to make it easier for users to install their software. Additionally some of the problems that have become apparent during the last few months, and their solutions will be explored.

event.title: The new zypp solver
event.abstract: The solver used in openSUSE 10.3 was rewritten from scratch. It is based on standard SAT algorithms (boolean satusfiability problem) and supports new features like OR dependencies. Plus, it is much faster than the old approach and presents the user with sensible suggestions if a conflicts are found.

event.title: Suspend
event.abstract: Status update. What happened during the last year, what are the new features / goodies ?

event.title: What nobody knows about YaST
event.abstract: Useful not well-known features, development tricks, debugging tips and roadmap.

event.title: Fun with Zeroconf
event.abstract:
• Brief introduction in Zeroconf
  • Development hints for Zeroconf applications
  • Demonstration of Zeroconf applications in openSUSE (synergy, kepas, ...)

event.title: OWASP WebScarab-NG
event.abstract: Rogan will talk briefly about the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP), then introduce, explain and demonstrate OWASP's WebScarab-NG testing tool.
event.description: WebScarab-NG allows the operator full access to the HTTP(S) protocol used between the browser and web server, including the ability to intercept, examine and modify requests and responses in-flight in various ways.

event.title: What can you do for PostgreSQL community
event.abstract: n/a

event.title: DBI-Link 3.0
event.abstract:
Have you ever needed to get data from a spreadsheet and put it in a database? Have you ever wanted to do real queries on a CSV file?

DBI-Link 3.0 makes these operations easy.
event.description:
For years, DBI-Link has been used in large production systems for communicating between Postgres and other data sources, not just other RDBMSs.

Find out what's new in the latest version, and make your migration easier.
