event.title: Win32 development in a Unix project
event.abstract: n/a

event.title: Mozilla Prism
event.abstract: Mozilla Prism is an application that lets users split web applications out of their browser and run them directly on their desktop.
event.description:
People have traditionally used desktop applications, but more and more of them are turning to web applications. Such applications often fit awkwardly into the document-centric interface of web browsers. This talk focuses on Mozilla Prism, an experiment for desktop-enabling web applications, and how the next generation of web APIs increase the capabilities of those applications by adding functionality to the Web itself.

Mark will also highlight some new features in Firefox 3, especially those that help the Mozilla platform become a better web application platform.

event.title: Contributions presentations (3)
event.abstract:
• Service oriented forge, by Olivier Abdoun, Ciaran Bryce and Adrian Mos
  • Open Research Issues Toward a Legal Framework for OSS, by Guillaume Rousseau
  • Security Engineering and Open Source Software Development, by Martin Gruhn

event.title: Demos
event.abstract: Demos of the different platforms developed by the research projects that organize the room

event.title: CSA on Rails: a practical case-study
event.abstract: This presentation aims at telling the story behind one of the first real-life implementations of RoR in a Belgian internet website. The CSA (Conseil supérieur de l'audiovisuel) is a public regulation authority for the media sector for the French community in Belgium. It is a small organization with approx. 20 full time agents, with a rather autonomous functioning.
event.description:
In January 2007, we launched a new website entirely based on RoR, with a lot of classical CMS features. The website was done on internal resources for 80% of the work. The development had stretched over 9 months (part time) and we are still continuously improving the solution. One particularity worth noting: using mostly internal resources implied to rely on people with little development background. Practically, the internal development was done by one agent with a good web design and multimedia project management background, who learned the technology on his way. The other 20% of the work was given to a RoR code monkey. His role was to give practical support to the lead developer, code some complex and time consuming features, and take care of the hosting and deployment solution.

The presentation will not be technical : you won't learn any undocumented tips and tricks about RoR here. Rather, it will mostly give the user/project manager point of view. The aim is to give feedback on our experience to people considering using the solution (as a report on the overall strengths and weaknesses of the solution), as well as nourishing a reflexion on the impact of using Rails on the way CSA works, and to what extent the found advantages are replicable.

event.title: RESTful best practices
event.abstract: RESTful practices are increasingly being adopted by the web community. They can help architecture a web application in a clean and structured way. However, it is not always evident to apply the RESTful principles. In this talk we will first cover the basics of REST in Rails. Then, we will present some use cases we meet in our projects.
event.description:
The whole Rails community is buzzing around REST. Indeed, it has been one of the most significant improvements of Rails since its first release in 2004. Rails made REST easy. However, using the RESTful features of Rails does not mean you will automatically use REST correctly. For many people, this REST thing is not crystal clear yet. In our talk, we will first remind the audience about the REST features of Rails.

Then, we will take a 10,000 feet view to approach the REST architectural concepts. Finally, we will illustrate these abstract concepts by actual case studies inspired by our everyday job. We will try to answer some basic questions like:

  • Why REST?
  • What is a resource?
* How does a RESTful URI looks like? * What is the relationship between REST and CRUD? * How does Rails handle REST? And some more advanced ones like:
  • How to get a resource in different formats?
  • How to create a RESTful wizard?
  • How to make my shopping cart RESTful?
  • What are the differences between SOA and REST?

event.title: Shoes, a versatile Ruby GUI toolkit
event.abstract: Shoes is a refreshingly new GUI toolkit for the Ruby language, written by the notorious _why.
event.description: Koen will present this shiny toolkit, including the improvements that Shoes has gone through in the recent months. If the demo-gods are benevolent, he'll demo a Twitter client written in Shoes, and give a look under the hood.

event.title: Using Rails for agile development of a job site
event.abstract: We will focus on the business and technical aspects of using Rails for a novel job site. What were the risks, how did we reduce them, which choices did we make, how did we develop, what are the results. Which technologies did we use (plug-in's, databases, full-text search, integration with debian stable, authentication and access control, ...).
event.description:
Peter will discuss (from a management viewpoint):

  • why did I choose Rails for this project
  • what where the perceived risks (maturity, scalability, security)
  • initial choices made (development methodology, short cycles, integrating early user interactions and feedback)
  • details on the full text search
  • getting this to run on Debian stable (etch)
  • the results
  • advise for other projects considering Rails
Koen will discuss (from a technical viewpoint):
  • technical architecture of the system
  • the development model
  • technical challenges and resolutions
  • the authentication model
  • security

event.title: SCons
event.abstract: This talk discusses use of the SCons build system for Open Source projects.
event.description:
SCons is a cross-platform software build system with a domain-specific configuration language implemented in Python, which provides the ability to configure builds with an expressive scripting language instead of static dependency definitions.

SCons emphasizes a whole-tree approach to managing the software dependency graph, including the ability to handle difficult configurations like automatically discovering dependencies in generated header files. SCons also contains integrated support for software packaging and Autoconf-like system configuration.

SCons is backed by a strong test-driven development methodology (lines of test code outnumber source code by about 2.4 to 1) to ensure the quality of contributions from more than 150 developers since the project's inception. The result is a software build tool with enough reliability and consistency for large-scale enterprise software builds.

This talk will walk through various best practices for configuring Open Source projects using SCons, including limitations and pitfalls to avoid.

event.title: VirtualBox
event.abstract: VirtualBox is a feature rich and powerful virtualization platform available for Linux, Windows, Mac OS, Solaris and other platforms.
event.description:
This talk starts with an overview of the product and shows the architecture and how it compares to other commercial and open solutions on the market.

Advanced virtualization topics such as hardware extensions and future trends and development will also be discussed.

event.title: Xen
event.abstract: Ian speaks about the factors that are making ubiquitous virtualization possible, as well as its advantages.
event.description:
Hypervisors are set to become ubiquitous on PC hardware, built-in to every server, and ultimately, every laptop too.

The open source Xen hypervisor is at the forefront of this movement, its architecture making it ideally suited for embedding in firmware and providing highly secure and efficient virtualization.

This talk looks at the hardware and software factors that are making ubiquitous virtualization possible, and discusses the benefits that virtualization brings to both data centres and personal computing devices.

Pratt will give a status update of the Xen project, and talk about some of the cool new things that are on the roadmap.

event.title: Fixing X input
event.abstract: X input is currently a horrible tangled mess. It's primarily comprised of three components: core input, which doesn't believe in multiple input devices or different layouts; XKB, which does everything for keyboards except mapping keys, and XInput, which enables applications to actually deal with input devices separately. XKB is a hacked-together mess that only the maintainer understands, and XInput is only used by one application. Input in X is currently undergoing a huge cleanup, and also growing to become useful, as with the multi-pointer X work.
event.description:
X input is currently a horrible mess of spaghetti code that is conceptually broken. But that's okay, because the implementation is also abysmal. At linux.conf.au, our fearless input ninjas (Daniel Stone and Petter Hutterer of MPX fame) sat down at a pub and devised a back-of-a-coaster plan to actually properly fix input once and for all, and make it even remotely understandable.

This talk will present the current problems, and the plan for moving forward.

event.title: Update on Gallium3D
event.abstract: Gallium3D is a new architecture for building 3D graphics drivers. Supporting the future OpenGL 3.0 specification, but being API-neutral, it will model the programmable rendering pipelines of modern graphics hardware.
event.description: This talk will give a status update on Gallium3D, after its introduction at the X Developer Summit in september.

event.title: Bringing Metisse and Xorg together
event.abstract: Mettisse is a 2.5d windowing system based on the X window system. Rather than being a new desktop environment, it is intended as a tool for creating new types of desktop environments.
event.description: This talk will feature demos on Metisse's current features, [[http://insitu.lri.fr/metisse/ Metisse]'s future directions and how Xorg integration will come into play with XComposite, GLX_EXT_texture_from_pixmap, input redirection, MPX, ...

event.title: Radeon, from DRM to Gallium
event.abstract: The talk will cover each part of the graphic pipeline under Linux as it is now and as it will likely be in the future.
event.description: It can be considered as a tutorial to the graphic pipeline viewed through the radeon driver work that Jerome is currently working on.

event.title: Roadmap to recovery - pain and redemption in X driver development
event.abstract: This talk will showcase a driver that satisfies the requirements of the kernel, X and desktop communities and offers new levels of functionality and performance.
event.description: Over the last several years, we've proposed dozens of potential architectures for support of graphics devices in a Linux environment. They have ranged from utterly lame to completely impractical, with only a few showing any potential at all. While this has taken a huge amount of time and energy, it looks to be finally coming to some kind of reasonable resolution.

event.title: Project VGA
event.abstract: Project VGA aims to create a fully open, low budget, VGA compatible video card. The specifications are: PCI, 100Mhz FPGA, 16MB SDRAM, VGA connector and USB for programming, all for less than 200EUR.
event.description: This talk will introduce Project VGA, it's goal and motivation, and will explain some of the design work and technology involved. When possible, initial hardware will also be demoed.

event.title: XAudio, an Audio extension for the X Window System
event.abstract: XAudio extends the X Window System to support audio processing; this extension is currently implemented as a loadable module for the X.org server. X clients can capture, playback and process audio through the X server.
event.description:
Audio processing is network transparent, optionally low-latency can be achieved through a shared memory mechanism. An audio manager performs functions analogous to the Window/Compositing manager, such as determining mix-down of streams from multiple clients.

The XAudio project aims to showcase the considerable benefits of integration compared to stand-alone audio daemons. And will demonstrate the feasibility of this approach and hopefully provide a standard implementation of this concept.
